<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, fuel expense was $150.7&nbsp;million compared to $165.8&nbsp;million in the same
period in 2006. The decrease was due to a $4.6&nbsp;million decrease in the average cost of fuel and a
$10.5&nbsp;million decrease in the KWH volume generated. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and
Florida PSC Matters &#150; Retail Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, fuel expense was $430.2&nbsp;million compared to $407.9&nbsp;million for the same
period in 2006. The increase was due to a $20.2&nbsp;million increase in the average cost of fuel as
well as a $2.1&nbsp;million increase due to the KWH volume generated. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150;
&#147;FERC and Florida PSC Matters &#150; Retail Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Non-affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, purchased power expense &#150; non-affiliates was $7.1&nbsp;million compared to
$5.8&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. The increase was due to a $1.4&nbsp;million increase
resulting from higher average cost per net KWH offset by a $0.1&nbsp;million decrease in KWH
purchases.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, purchased power expense &#150; non-affiliates was $10.5&nbsp;million compared to $15.2
million in the corresponding period in 2006. The decrease was due to a $2.2&nbsp;million decrease in
KWH purchases and a $2.5&nbsp;million decrease resulting from lower cost per net KWH.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Energy purchases from non-affiliates will vary depending on market cost of available energy being
lower than Southern Company system-generated energy, demand for energy within the system service
territory, and availability of Southern Company system generation.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->84<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, purchased power &#150; affiliates was $36.7&nbsp;million compared to $28.8&nbsp;million
for the corresponding period in 2006. The increase was due to a $44.3&nbsp;million increase in KWH
purchases offset by a $36.4&nbsp;million decrease resulting from lower average cost per net KWH.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, purchased power &#150; affiliates was $54.2&nbsp;million compared to $50.9&nbsp;million for
the corresponding period in 2006. The increase was due to a $5.5&nbsp;million increase in KWH purchases
offset by a $2.2&nbsp;million decrease resulting from lower average cost per net KWH.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Energy purchases from affiliated companies within the Southern Company system will vary depending
on demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company. These purchases
are made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC.
</DIV>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, other operations and maintenance expenses were $70.5&nbsp;million compared to
$60.4&nbsp;million in the same period in 2006. This was primarily a result of a $1.0&nbsp;million increase
in employee benefit expenses, a $2.4&nbsp;million increase in production expenses associated with
increased operating expenses and maintenance performed on power generation facilities, a $2.1
million increase in other energy services, which did not have a material impact on earnings since
they were offset by associated revenues, a $2.1&nbsp;million increase in distribution expenses related
to vegetation management and labor cost, and a $0.6&nbsp;million increase in customer accounts related
to uncollectible accounts.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, other operations and maintenance expenses were $196.1&nbsp;million compared to
$181.4&nbsp;million for the same period in 2006. The increase was primarily the result of a $4.7
million increase in other energy services, which did not have a material impact on earnings since
they were offset by associated revenues, and a $2.9&nbsp;million increase in production operating
expense. Also contributing to the increase was a $4.5&nbsp;million in additional scheduled and
unscheduled maintenance performed on power generation facilities and a $1.5&nbsp;million in additional
vegetation management expense.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, depreciation and amortization expenses were $21.5&nbsp;million compared to
$22.3&nbsp;million in the same period in 2006. For year-to-date 2007, depreciation and amortization
expenses were $63.8&nbsp;million
compared to $66.6&nbsp;million in the same period in 2006. The decreases for both periods were the
result of new depreciation rates implemented in January&nbsp;2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, taxes
other than income taxes were $25.0&nbsp;million compared to $23.3

$65.5&nbsp;million compared to $62.0&nbsp;million for the same period in 2006. These increases were

to increases in retail revenues.

    <TD align="right">11.2</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="13" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, interest
expense was $10.9&nbsp;million compared to $10.0&nbsp;million in the same
period in 2006. For year-to-date 2007, interest expense was $32.3&nbsp;million compared to $29.1
million in the same period in 2006. These increases were primarily due to the issuance of $110
million in senior notes in December&nbsp;2006 and the issuance of $85&nbsp;million in senior notes in June
2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Income Taxes</I></B>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, income tax expense was $19.9&nbsp;million compared to $21.5&nbsp;million in the
same period in 2006. The decrease was primarily a result of lower earnings before income taxes,
the tax benefit associated with an increase in allowance for equity funds used during construction,
and an increase in the deduction created by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004. See Note (H)
to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, income tax expense was $44.3&nbsp;million compared to $42.9&nbsp;million for the same
period in 2006. The increase was primarily a result of higher earnings before income taxes. The
increase was partially offset by the tax benefit associated with an increase in allowance for
equity funds used during construction and an increase in the deduction created by the American Jobs
Creation Act of 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Gulf Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. The level of Gulf Power&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous factors that
affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Gulf Power&#146;s business of selling electricity.
These factors include Gulf Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory environment that
continues to allow for the recovery of all prudently incurred costs during a time of increasing
costs. Future earnings in the near term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales, which
is subject to a number of factors. These factors include weather, competition, new energy
contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of
electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic growth in Gulf Power&#146;s
service area. For additional information relating to these issues, see RISK FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A and
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the
Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be fully recovered in rates on a timely basis. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Gulf Power in Item
7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Eight-Hour Ozone Regulations</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150;
Environmental Statutes and Regulations &#150; Air Quality&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
additional information regarding revisions to the eight-hour ozone air quality standard. On June
20, 2007, the EPA proposed additional revisions to the current eight-hour ozone standard which, if
enacted, could result in designation of new nonattainment areas within Gulf Power&#146;s service
territory. The EPA has requested comment and is expected to make a determination regarding
finalization of a revised standard in 2008. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be
determined at this time.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->87<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fine Particulate Matter Regulations</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150;
Environmental Statutes and Regulations &#150; Air Quality&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
additional information regarding nonattainment designations for the fine particulate matter air
quality standard. In March&nbsp;2007, the EPA finalized its fine particulate matter implementation
rule, requiring submittal of state plans for addressing the nonattainment designations by April
2008. The ultimate outcome of this matter depends on the development and submittal of those state
plans and the resolution of pending legal challenges and, therefore, cannot be determined at this
time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Florida Greenhouse Gas Executive Orders</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters -
Global Climate Issues&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information
regarding domestic efforts to reduce greenhouse gases. On July&nbsp;13, 2007, the Governor of the State
of Florida signed three executive orders addressing reduction of greenhouse gas emissions within
the state, including statewide emission reduction targets beginning in 2017. Included in the
orders is a directive to the Secretary of Environmental Protection to develop rules adopting
maximum allowable emissions levels of greenhouse gases for electric utilities, consistent with the
statewide emission reduction targets, and a request to the Florida PSC to initiate rulemaking
requiring utilities to produce at least 20% of their electricity from renewable sources. The
impact of these orders on Gulf Power will depend on the development, adoption, and implementation
of any rules governing greenhouse gas emissions, and the ultimate outcome cannot be determined at
this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Georgia Multi-Pollutant Rule</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On June&nbsp;27, 2007, the State of Georgia approved a new &#147;multi-pollutant&#148; rule for certain existing
coal-fired electric utility steam generating units in Georgia. The rule is designed to reduce
emissions of mercury, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, and fine particulates state-wide by requiring
installation of specified control technologies at each affected unit by a date certain between
December&nbsp;31, 2008 and June&nbsp;1, 2015. This rule will require the installation of a new pollution
control system at Plant Scherer Unit 3 which Gulf Power co-owns with Georgia Power. See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150;
Environmental Statutes and Regulations &#150; General&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a discussion of
estimated compliance costs for 2007 through 2009. The ultimate impact of this rule on Gulf Power
cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Environmental Remediation</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the second quarter 2007, Gulf Power increased its estimated liability for environmental
remediation projects by $12.8&nbsp;million as a result of changes in the cost estimates to remediate
substation sites. These projects have been approved by the Florida PSC for recovery through the
environmental cost recovery clause; therefore, there was no impact on Gulf Power&#146;s net income as a
result of these revised estimates. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS
POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; Environmental Remediation&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3
to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; Environmental Remediation&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->88<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and Florida PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150;
Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of
Gulf Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
information regarding the proceedings initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess Southern
Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory and in May&nbsp;2005 to determine
whether Southern Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate
analysis: transmission market power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal
dealing.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In late June and July&nbsp;2007, hearings were held in the December&nbsp;2004 proceeding and briefs to the
presiding ALJ were filed in August and September. Gulf Power anticipates an initial decision
from the ALJ in November&nbsp;2007 on the issues that were set for hearing. The ultimate outcome of
this generation dominance proceeding cannot now be determined, but an adverse decision by the
FERC in a final order could result in refunds of approximately $0.8&nbsp;million, plus interest.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On June&nbsp;21, 2007, the FERC issued an order terminating the May&nbsp;2005 proceeding pertaining to the
other three parts of the market-based rate analysis. In addition, on June&nbsp;21, 2007, the FERC
issued its final rule regarding market-based rate authority. The FERC generally retained its
current market-based rate standards. The impact of this order and its effect on the generation
dominance proceeding cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150;
Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Gulf Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for information regarding the proceeding initiated by the FERC in May&nbsp;2005 to
examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power,
Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of
which the Power Pool is operated, and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion
of Southern Power as a party to the IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the
FERC&#146;s standards of conduct applicable to utility companies that are transmission providers, and
(3)&nbsp;whether Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148;
rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just and reasonable.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On April&nbsp;19, 2007, the FERC approved, with certain modifications, the compliance filing
submitted by Southern Company on November&nbsp;6, 2006. The compliance plan largely involves
functional separation and information restrictions related to marketing activities conducted on
behalf of Southern Power. Implementation of the plan is not expected to have a material impact
on Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power has established fuel cost recovery rates approved by the Florida PSC. In recent
years, Gulf Power has experienced higher than expected fuel costs for coal and natural gas. If
the projected fuel over or under recovery exceeds 10% of the projected fuel revenue applicable
for the period, Gulf Power is required to notify the Florida PSC and to indicate if an
adjustment to the fuel cost recovery factor is being requested. Gulf Power filed such notice
with the Florida PSC on June&nbsp;15, 2007, but no adjustment to the factor was requested. Under
recovered fuel costs at September&nbsp;30, 2007 totaled $64.2&nbsp;million, and are included in
under recovered regulatory clause revenues on Gulf Power&#146;s Condensed Balance Sheets herein.
Fuel cost recovery
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->89<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">revenues, as recorded on the financial statements, are adjusted for differences in actual
recoverable costs and amounts billed in current regulated rates. Accordingly, any changes in
the billing factor would have no significant effect on Gulf Power&#146;s revenues or net income, but
will affect cash flow. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150;
&#147;PSC Matters &#150; Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 1 to the financial
statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Revenues&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Other</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On August&nbsp;14, 2007, the Florida PSC voted to approve a stipulation among Gulf Power, the Office
of Public Counsel, and the Florida Industrial Power Users Group regarding Gulf Power&#146;s plan for
complying with certain federal and state regulations addressing air quality. Gulf Power&#146;s
environmental compliance plan as filed on March&nbsp;29, 2007 contemplates implementation of specific
projects identified in the plan from 2007 through 2018. The stipulation covers all elements of
the current plan that are scheduled to be implemented in the 2007-2011 timeframe. See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital Requirements
and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 7 to the financial statements of
Gulf Power under &#147;Construction Program&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Property Tax Dispute&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K for information on the property tax dispute with Monroe County, Georgia. The
administrative appeals and notices of arbitration have been expanded to include tax year 2006. The
appeals remain stayed pending the outcome of the related litigation. On March&nbsp;30, 2007, the
Georgia Court of Appeals reversed the trial court and ruled that the Monroe County Board of Tax
Assessors (Monroe Board) had exceeded its legal authority and remanded the case for entry of an
injunction prohibiting the Monroe Board from collecting taxes based on its independent valuation of
Plant Scherer. In April&nbsp;2007, the Monroe Board filed a petition with the Georgia Supreme Court
requesting review of the decision of the Georgia Court of Appeals. On July&nbsp;16, 2007, the Georgia
Supreme Court agreed to hear the Monroe Board&#146;s requested review of this decision. The Georgia
Supreme Court heard oral arguments regarding the matter on October&nbsp;15, 2007. Gulf Power could be
subject to total taxes through September&nbsp;30, 2007 of up to $3.9&nbsp;million, plus penalties and
interest. In accordance with Gulf Power&#146;s unit power sales contract for Plant Scherer, such
property taxes would be recoverable from the customer. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot
currently be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power is in the process of offering both voluntary and involuntary severance to a number of
employees in connection with a reorganization of certain functions. Gulf Power expects to incur
approximately $4.9&nbsp;million in expenses related to severance benefits and termination costs. A
portion of these anticipated severance benefits resulted in expenses during the third quarter 2007.
The remainder of the anticipated severance benefits is expected to be expensed during the fourth
quarter 2007. The actual amount and timing of these charges may differ materially from the
estimate described above and will depend upon the final composition and seniority of the affected
employees and the actual timing of completion of the planned reorganization.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Right of Way Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for information on the lawsuits related to the telecommunication use of rights of
way. In September&nbsp;2007, Gulf Power and its co-defendant in the Gadsden County litigation reached a
proposed settlement agreement with the plaintiffs that, if approved by the trial court, will
resolve all outstanding claims against Gulf Power in both the Gadsden County litigation and the
2001 telecommunications company litigation. If so approved, the
settlement will have no material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements. Pending final
settlement approval, the ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->90<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Gulf Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive governmental
regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, common law nuisance, and
citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as opacity and air quality standards, has
increased generally throughout the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for
damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate
outcome of such pending or potential litigation against Gulf Power cannot be predicted at this
time; however, for current proceedings not specifically reported herein or in Note 3 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K, management does not anticipate that
the liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect
on Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and
Estimates&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Gulf Power&#146;s
critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation, Contingent
Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Income Taxes</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On January&nbsp;1, 2007, Gulf Power adopted FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 (FIN 48), &#147;Accounting for
Uncertainty in Income Taxes.&#148; FIN 48 requires companies to determine whether it is &#147;more likely
than not&#148; that a tax position will be sustained upon examination by the appropriate taxing
authorities before any part of the benefit can be recorded in the financial statements. It also
provides guidance on the recognition, measurement, and classification of income tax uncertainties,
along with any related interest and penalties. The provisions of FIN 48 were applied to all tax
positions beginning January&nbsp;1, 2007. The adoption of FIN 48 did not have a material impact on Gulf
Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fair Value Measurement</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;157 (SFAS No.&nbsp;157), &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; in September&nbsp;2006.
This standard provides guidance on how to measure fair value where it is permitted or required
under other accounting pronouncements. SFAS No.&nbsp;157 also requires additional disclosures about
fair value measurements. Gulf Power plans to adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;157 on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and is
currently assessing the impact of this standard.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->91<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fair Value Option</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In February&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;159 (SFAS No.&nbsp;159), &#147;Fair Value Option for
Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities &#151; Including an Amendment of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;115.&#148;
This standard permits an entity to choose to measure many financial instruments and certain other
items at fair value. Gulf Power plans to adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;159 on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and is currently
assessing its impact to the extent the fair value option is elected.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power&#146;s financial condition and liquidity position remained stable at September&nbsp;30, 2007. Net cash
provided from operating activities totaled $164.5&nbsp;million for the first nine months of 2007,
compared to $117.3&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. The $47.2&nbsp;million increase in
cash provided from operating activities in the first nine months of 2007 is primarily due to
increased cash inflows for fuel cost recovery. Net cash used for investing activities totaled
$178.7&nbsp;million primarily due to gross property additions to utility plant of $160.9&nbsp;million in the
first nine months of 2007. These additions were primarily related to installation of equipment to
comply with environmental standards and distribution facilities construction. Net cash provided
from financing activities totaled $11.6&nbsp;million for the first nine months of 2007, compared to
$11.1&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. The change in net cash provided from financing
activities was not material.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#150;</FONT> &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Gulf Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, lease obligations,
preference stock dividends, purchase commitments, and trust funding requirements. Approximately
$41.2&nbsp;million will be required through September&nbsp;30, 2008 for redemptions and maturities of
long-term debt.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On April&nbsp;16, 2007 the Florida PSC issued an order approving two PPAs that Gulf Power had previously
entered into, one of which is with Southern Power, for a total of 487 MW annually from June&nbsp;2009
through May&nbsp;2014. The PPA with Southern Power was approved by the FERC on July&nbsp;13, 2007. See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital Requirements
and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those utilized in the past. Recently, Gulf Power has primarily utilized funds from
operating cash flows, short-term debt, external security offerings, and equity contributions from
Southern Company. However, the amount, type, and timing of any future financings, if needed, will
depend upon regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Gulf Power in
Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->92<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power&#146;s current liabilities frequently exceed current assets because of the continued use of
short-term debt as a funding source to meet scheduled maturities of long-term debt as well as cash
needs which can fluctuate significantly due to the seasonality of the business. To meet short-term
cash needs and contingencies, Gulf Power had at September&nbsp;30, 2007 approximately $4.9&nbsp;million of
cash and cash equivalents and $125&nbsp;million of unused committed lines of credit with banks. Of the
unused credit agreements, $60&nbsp;million expire in 2007 and $65&nbsp;million expire in 2008. Subsequent to
September&nbsp;30, 2007, Gulf Power renewed the $60&nbsp;million of its facilities that were set to expire in
2007. All $125&nbsp;million of facilities now contain a 2008 expiration date and $100&nbsp;million include
one-year term loan options. Gulf Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to
expiration. See Note 6 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Bank Credit Arrangements&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. These credit arrangements provide liquidity
support to Gulf Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and
commercial paper. Gulf Power may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company
subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the
request and for the benefit of Gulf Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At September
30, 2007, Gulf Power had $25.6&nbsp;million of commercial paper outstanding. Management believes that
the need for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial paper programs and lines
of credit without maintaining large cash balances.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain contracts
that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change
to BBB- or Baa3, or below. Generally, collateral may be provided for by a Southern Company
guaranty, letter of credit, or cash. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales. At September&nbsp;30, 2007, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a
BBB- or Baa3 rating were approximately $23.1&nbsp;million. The maximum potential collateral
requirements at a rating below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $46.3&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power, along with all members of the Power Pool, is also party to certain agreements that
could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating change to below
investment grade for Alabama Power and/or Georgia Power. These agreements are primarily for natural
gas and power price risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2007, Gulf Power&#146;s total exposure
to these types of agreements was $26.7&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed materially
compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2006 reporting period. In addition, Gulf Power is not aware of any
facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Due to cost-based rate regulation, Gulf Power has limited exposure to market volatility in interest
rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to
movements in electricity prices, Gulf Power enters into physical fixed-price contracts for the
purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market. Gulf Power has also
implemented a fuel-hedging program with the approval of the Florida PSC.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->93<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Unrealized gains and losses from mark-to-market adjustments on derivative contracts related to Gulf
Power&#146;s fuel hedging programs are recorded as regulatory assets and liabilities. Realized gains
and losses from these programs are included in fuel expense and are recovered through Gulf Power&#146;s
fuel cost recovery clause. Gains and losses on derivative energy contracts that are not designated
as hedges are recognized in the statements of income as incurred.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">At September&nbsp;30, 2007, the fair value gain/(loss) of derivative energy contracts was reflected in
the financial statements as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="81%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000"><B>Amounts</B></TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><I>(in thousands)</I></TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #cceeff">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Regulatory assets, net</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">(1,968</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Unrealized pre-tax gains and losses recognized in income were not material for any period
presented.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)&nbsp;to
the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->94<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In January&nbsp;2007, Gulf Power issued 800,000 shares of common stock to Southern Company at $100
stated value per share ($80&nbsp;million aggregate purchase price). The proceeds were used to repay a
portion of Gulf Power&#146;s short-term indebtedness and for other general corporate purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In March&nbsp;2007, Gulf Power entered into derivative transactions designed to mitigate interest rate
risk related to future planned debt issuances. The total notional amount of these derivatives was
$165&nbsp;million. Of this $165&nbsp;million, $85&nbsp;million was terminated in June&nbsp;2007 when the underlying
security was issued at a gain of $3&nbsp;million. This gain will be amortized over a 10-year period.
See Note (F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for further details.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In June&nbsp;2007, Gulf Power issued $85&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;2007A 5.90% Senior Notes due June&nbsp;15, 2017.
Proceeds were used to repay a portion of its outstanding short-term indebtedness and for general
corporate purposes, including Gulf Power&#146;s continuous construction program.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Subsequent to September&nbsp;30, 2007, Gulf Power issued $45&nbsp;million of 6.45% Preference Stock.
Proceeds were used to repay a portion of its outstanding short-term indebtedness and for general
corporate purposes, including its continuous construction program.<BR>
In October&nbsp;2007, Gulf Power issued a notice of redemption to the holders of the $41.2&nbsp;million of
Gulf Power Series&nbsp;E Junior Subordinated Notes due November&nbsp;30, 2042 and the related trust preferred
and common securities of Gulf Power Capital Trust IV. All securities in this series will be
redeemed in November&nbsp;2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements, contractual
obligations, and storm-recovery, Gulf Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a
program to retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if
market conditions permit.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->95<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<DIV align="left">
<A name="128"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<br>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">THIRD QUARTER 2007 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2006<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2007 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2006

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power operates as a vertically integrated utility providing electricity to retail
customers within its traditional service area located within the State of Mississippi and to
wholesale customers in the Southeast. Many factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks
of Mississippi Power&#146;s business of selling electricity. These factors include the ability to
maintain a stable regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth, and to effectively manage
and secure timely recovery of rising costs. These costs include those related to growing demand,
increasingly stringent environmental standards, fuel prices, and storm restoration following
Hurricane Katrina.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power continues to focus on several key performance indicators. In recognition that
Mississippi Power&#146;s long-term financial success is dependent upon how well it satisfies its
customers&#146; needs, Mississippi Power&#146;s retail base rate mechanism, PEP, includes performance
indicators that directly tie customer service indicators to Mississippi Power&#146;s allowed return. In
addition to the PEP performance indicators, Mississippi Power focuses on other performance
measures, including broader measures of customer satisfaction, plant availability, system
reliability, and net income. For additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#150; &#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of
the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Net Income</I></B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">Third Quarter 2007 vs. Third Quarter 2006</TD>
    <TD style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">Year-to-Date 2007 vs. Year-to-Date 2006</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(change in millions)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(% change)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(change in millions)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(% change)</I></TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center" valign="top"><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">$(2.1)
</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">(6.0)
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">$5.7
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">7.6</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="7" valign="top" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the third quarter 2007 was
$34.5&nbsp;million compared to $36.6&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. The decrease was
primarily due to the regulatory liability created with the establishment of the System Restoration
Rider (SRR). Currently, Mississippi Power estimates a credit due to retail
customers for the SRR clause when the regulatory liability is settled. See FUTURE EARNINGS
POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and Mississippi PSC Matters &#150; Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; herein for additional
information. The decrease in net income is also attributable to an increase in depreciation and
amortization due to the amortization of a regulatory liability related to Plant Daniel capacity for
the third quarter 2007, an increase in other operations and maintenance expenses, and a decrease in
total other income and (expense). These items were partially offset by increases in territorial
base revenues and in wholesale energy revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for year-to-date 2007 was $80.4
million compared to $74.7&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. The increase was primarily
due to increases in territorial base revenues which was a result of a retail base rate increase
effective April&nbsp;1, 2006, sales growth,
wholesale energy revenues, and total other income and (expense). These increases were partially
offset by an increase in other operations and maintenance expenses, an increase in depreciation and
amortization due to the amortization of a regulatory liability related to Plant Daniel capacity for
the year-to-date 2007, and a decrease in SRR retail revenues as discussed above.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->101<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Retail Revenues</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, retail revenues were $221.8&nbsp;million compared to $200.9&nbsp;million in the
same period in 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, retail revenues were $560.1&nbsp;million compared to $505.4&nbsp;million for the same
period in 2006.
</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Revenue associated with changes in rates and pricing decreased in the third quarter 2007 when
compared to the same period of 2006 primarily due to retail revenue reductions of approximately
$2.2&nbsp;million related to the SRR and a one time credit to retail customers of approximately $1.1
million related to PEP. This decrease was partially offset by an increase in the ECO Plan rate
effective May&nbsp;2007 of approximately $2.3&nbsp;million. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and
Mississippi PSC Matters &#150; Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Revenue associated with changes in rates and pricing increased for year-to-date 2007 when compared
to the same period of 2006 due to a base rate increase effective April&nbsp;2006 and increase in the ECO
Plan rate effective May&nbsp;2007 of approximately $8.5&nbsp;million. This increase was partially offset by
retail revenue reductions of approximately $1.8&nbsp;million related to the SRR and a one time credit to
retail customers of approximately $1.1&nbsp;million related to PEP.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Revenues attributable to changes in sales growth increased in the third quarter 2007 when compared
to the same period in 2006 due to 0.9% and 6.5% increases in KWH sales to residential and
commercial customers, respectively, primarily due to increase in usage and customer loads returning
after Hurricane Katrina.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Revenues attributable to changes in sales growth increased for year-to-date 2007 when compared to
the same period in 2006 due to 1.7%, 8.5%, and 4.5% increases in KWH sales to residential,
commercial, and industrial customers, respectively, primarily due to increase in usage and customer
loads returning after Hurricane Katrina.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Revenues resulting from changes in weather decreased because of mild weather in the third quarter
and year-to-date 2007 compared to normal weather in the third quarter and year-to-date 2006.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->102<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Fuel revenues increased in the third quarter and year-to-date 2007 when compared to the same
periods in 2006. Electric rates include provisions to adjust billings for fluctuations in fuel
costs, including the energy component of purchased power costs. Under these provisions, fuel
revenues generally equal fuel expenses, including the fuel component of purchased power costs, and
do not affect net income.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Wholesale Revenues &#150; Non-Affiliates</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">Third Quarter 2007 vs. Third Quarter 2006</TD>
    <TD style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">Year-to-Date 2007 vs. Year-to-Date 2006</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(change in millions)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(% change)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(change in millions)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(% change)</I></TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center" valign="top"><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">$17.3
</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">22.5
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">$43.2
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">21.2</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="7" valign="top" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, wholesale revenues from non-affiliates were $93.8&nbsp;million compared to
$76.5&nbsp;million in the same period in 2006. The increase was primarily due to increased sales to
customers within Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory of $9.5&nbsp;million and increased sales to
customers outside Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory of $7.7&nbsp;million. The $9.5&nbsp;million increase
in revenues to customers within Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory was primarily due to an $8.5
million increase in fuel costs and a $1.0&nbsp;million increase in base revenue due to higher demand by
customers. The $7.7&nbsp;million increase in sales to customers outside Mississippi Power&#146;s service
territory was primarily due to a $6.8&nbsp;million increase in energy revenues and a $0.9&nbsp;million
increase in capacity revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, wholesale revenues to non-affiliates were $247.7&nbsp;million compared to $204.5
million for the same period in 2006. The increase was primarily due to increased sales to
customers outside Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory of $21.8&nbsp;million and increased sales to
customers within Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory of $21.4&nbsp;million. The $21.8&nbsp;million
increase in sales to customers outside Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory was primarily due to a
$19.0&nbsp;million increase in energy revenues and a $2.8&nbsp;million increase in capacity revenues. The
$21.4&nbsp;million increase in revenues to customers within Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory was
primarily due to a $17.3&nbsp;million increase in fuel costs and a $4.1&nbsp;million increase in base revenue
due to higher demand by customers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Revenues from wholesale sales to non-affiliates will vary depending on the market cost of available
energy compared to the cost of Mississippi Power and Southern Company system owned generation,
demand for energy within the Southern Company service territory, and availability of Southern
Company system generation.
</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, wholesale revenues to affiliates were $13.7&nbsp;million compared to $29.5
million in the same period in 2006. The decrease was primarily due to a $14.4&nbsp;million decrease in
energy revenues, of which a $16.6&nbsp;million decrease was associated with decreased sales, partially
offset by a $2.2&nbsp;million increase associated with higher prices. Capacity revenues decreased $1.5
million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, wholesale revenues to affiliates were $42.2&nbsp;million compared to $52.1
million for the same period in 2006. The decrease was primarily due to a $6.9&nbsp;million decrease in
energy revenues, of which a $2.3&nbsp;million decrease was associated with decreased sales and a $4.6
million decrease was associated with lower prices. Capacity revenues decreased $2.9&nbsp;million.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->103<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Revenues from wholesale sales to affiliates will vary depending on demand and the availability and
cost of generating resources at each company. These affiliate sales are made in accordance with
the IIC, as approved by the FERC. These transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings
since the energy is generally sold at marginal cost.
</DIV>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, total fuel and purchased power expenses were $180.3&nbsp;million compared to
$162.6&nbsp;million in the same period in 2006. The net increase in fuel and purchased power expenses
was primarily due to a $17.8&nbsp;million increase in the average cost of fuel and purchased power.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For
year-to-date 2007, total fuel and purchased power expenses were $456.0&nbsp;million compared to $391.0
million for the same period in 2006. The net increase in fuel and purchased power expenses was
primarily due to a $35.2&nbsp;million increase in the average cost of fuel and purchased power as well
as a $29.7&nbsp;million increase due to the KWH volume generated or purchased.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Fuel and purchased power transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings since the energy
purchases are generally offset by energy revenues through Mississippi Power&#146;s retail and wholesale
fuel cost recovery clauses.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Details of Mississippi Power&#146;s cost of generation and purchased power are as follows:
</DIV>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, fuel expense was $146.9&nbsp;million compared to $148.0&nbsp;million in the same
period in 2006. The decrease was primarily due to a $14.5&nbsp;million decrease in generation from
Mississippi Power-owned facilities, partially offset by a $13.4&nbsp;million increase in the cost of
fuel.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, fuel expense was $390.8&nbsp;million compared to $330.6&nbsp;million for the same
period in 2006. The increase was primarily due to a $33.2&nbsp;million increase in the cost of fuel and
a $27.0&nbsp;million increase in generation from Mississippi Power-owned facilities.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Non-affiliates</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, purchased power expense &#150; non-affiliates was $6.0&nbsp;million compared to
$5.8&nbsp;million in the same period in 2006. The increase was primarily the result of a 79.4% increase
in KWH volume
purchased due to less of Mississippi Power&#146;s generation being available to meet customer demand,
partially offset by a 42.6% decrease in the average cost of purchased power per KWH.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->104<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, purchased power expense &#150; non-affiliates was $8.2&nbsp;million compared to $15.1
million for the same period in 2006. The decrease was primarily the result of a 34.1% decrease in
the average cost of purchased power per KWH and a 17.9% decrease in KWH volume purchased due to
more of Mississippi Power&#146;s generation being available to meet customer demand.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Energy purchases from non-affiliates will vary depending on market cost of available energy being
lower than Southern Company system-generated energy, demand for energy within the system service
territory, and availability of Southern Company system generation.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Affiliates</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, purchased power &#150; affiliates was $27.5&nbsp;million compared to $8.9&nbsp;million
in the same period in 2006. The increase was primarily due to a 45.9% increase in the average cost
of purchased power per KWH as well as a 113.0% increase in KWH volume purchased, which was
primarily due to reduced generation resulting in more purchased power needed to meet the gap
between generation and demand, and more sales outside the Southern Company system.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, purchased power &#150; affiliates was $57.0&nbsp;million compared to $45.3&nbsp;million for
the same period in 2006. The increase was primarily due to an 8.1% increase in the average cost of
purchased power per KWH as well as a 16.5% increase in KWH volume purchased, which was primarily
due to more sales outside the Southern Company system.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Energy purchases from affiliated companies within the Southern Company system will vary depending
on demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company. These purchases
are made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC. These transactions did not have a
significant impact on earnings since the energy purchases are generally offset by energy revenues
through Mississippi Power&#146;s retail and wholesale fuel cost recovery clauses.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Other Operations and Maintenance Expenses</I></B>
</DIV>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD nowrap colspan="2" align="right" style="border-top: 3px double #000000; border-top: 3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, other operations and maintenance expenses were $61.2&nbsp;million compared to
$59.3&nbsp;million in the same period in 2006. The increase in other operations expense was primarily
due to a $1.1&nbsp;million increase in the wholesale portion of generation construction project
screening expenses and a general increase in other operations expense across all functions,
resulting from a $1.2&nbsp;million increase in internal labor costs, and a $0.8&nbsp;million increase in
outside and other contract services. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Other Matters&#148; herein for
additional information regarding generation construction project screening expenses. The decrease
in maintenance expense for the third quarter 2007 was primarily due to a decrease in production
expenses for baseline projects and a decrease in transmission and distribution maintenance expense
due primarily to the deferral of these expenses pursuant to an April&nbsp;2007 regulatory accounting
order from the Mississippi PSC. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and
Mississippi PSC Matters &#150; Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; herein for additional information regarding
the deferral of transmission and distribution maintenance expenses.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->105<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, other operations and maintenance expenses were $179.4&nbsp;million compared to
$171.5&nbsp;million for the same period in 2006. The increase in other operations expense was primarily
due to a $3.3&nbsp;million insurance recovery for 2005 storm restoration costs recognized in 2006, a
$2.0&nbsp;million increase in employee benefit expenses which is primarily due to an increase in medical
expense, a $1.7&nbsp;million increase in the wholesale portion of generation construction project
screening expenses, and a $4.6&nbsp;million increase in other operations expense across all functions
primarily resulting from increases in internal labor cost and outside and other contract services.
The decrease in maintenance expense for year-to-date 2007 was primarily due to a $1.2&nbsp;million
decrease in generation maintenance expense primarily due to outage work in 2006 and a $2.5&nbsp;million
decrease in transmission and distribution maintenance expense due primarily to the deferral of
these expenses pursuant to the regulatory accounting order from the Mississippi PSC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Depreciation and Amortization</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">Third Quarter 2007 vs. Third Quarter 2006</TD>
    <TD style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">Year-to-Date 2007 vs. Year-to-Date 2006</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(change in millions)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(% change)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(change in millions)</I></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center"><I>(% change)</I></TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center" valign="top"><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">$4.7
</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">44.5
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">$9.8
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">28.0</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="7" valign="top" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, depreciation and amortization was $15.3&nbsp;million compared to $10.6
million in the same period in 2006. The increase was primarily due to a $2.5&nbsp;million increase in
amortization of environmental costs related to the approved ECO Plan and a $1.8&nbsp;million increase in
amortization related to a regulatory liability recorded in 2003 in connection with the Mississippi
PSC&#146;s accounting order on Plant Daniel capacity. See Note 3 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, depreciation and amortization was $44.7&nbsp;million compared to $34.9&nbsp;million
for the same period in 2006. The increase was primarily due to a $3.2&nbsp;million increase in
amortization of environmental costs related to the approved ECO Plan and a $5.5&nbsp;million increase in
amortization related to a regulatory liability recorded in 2003 in connection with the Mississippi
PSC&#146;s accounting order on Plant Daniel capacity.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Total Other Income and (Expense)</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, total other income and (expense)&nbsp;was $(3.9) million compared to $(2.8)

</DIV>

million for the same period in 2006. The change was primarily the result of a $3.7&nbsp;million gain on
a contract termination approved by the FERC in the second quarter 2007, a $1.3&nbsp;million decrease in
interest on early redemption of long-term debt payable to affiliated trusts, partially offset by a
$1.3&nbsp;million decrease related to the recovery mechanism for fuel hedging and energy cost hedging
and $1.3&nbsp;million increase in interest on short-term indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Income Taxes</I></B>
</DIV>
