</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter and year-to-date 2007, income taxes were $20.8&nbsp;million and $49.0&nbsp;million,
respectively, compared to $22.4&nbsp;million and $45.4&nbsp;million, respectively, in the same periods in
2006. The changes were primarily due to the changes in pre-tax income.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Mississippi Power&#146;s
future earnings potential. The level of Mississippi Power&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous
factors that affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Mississippi Power&#146;s business of
selling electricity. These factors include Mississippi Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable
regulatory environment that continues to allow for the recovery of all prudently incurred costs
during a time of increasing costs. Future earnings in the near term will depend, in part, upon
growth in energy sales, which is subject to a number of factors. These factors include weather,
competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation practiced by
customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic
growth in Mississippi Power&#146;s service area in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. For additional
information relating to these issues, see RISK
FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of
Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be fully recovered in rates on a timely basis. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Mississippi Power
in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Eight-Hour Ozone Regulations</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150;
Environmental Statutes and Regulations &#150; Air Quality&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form
10-K for additional information regarding revisions to the eight-hour ozone air quality standard.
On June&nbsp;20, 2007, the EPA proposed additional revisions to the current eight-hour ozone standard
which, if enacted, could result in designation of new nonattainment areas within Mississippi
Power&#146;s service territory. The EPA has requested comment and is expected to make a determination
regarding finalization of a revised standard in 2008. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot
be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and Mississippi PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150;
Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the
Form 10-K for information regarding the proceedings initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to
assess Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory and in May
2005 to determine
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->107<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">whether Southern Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate
analysis: transmission market power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal
dealing.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In late June and July&nbsp;2007, hearings were held in the December&nbsp;2004 proceeding and briefs to the
presiding ALJ were filed in August and September. Mississippi Power anticipates an initial
decision from the ALJ in November&nbsp;2007 on the issues that were set for hearing. The ultimate
outcome of this generation dominance proceeding cannot now be determined, but an adverse
decision by the FERC in a final order could result in refunds of approximately $8.4&nbsp;million,
plus interest.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On June&nbsp;21, 2007, the FERC issued an order terminating the May&nbsp;2005 proceeding pertaining to the
other three parts of the market-based rate analysis. In addition, on June&nbsp;21, 2007, the FERC
issued its final rule regarding market-based rate authority. The FERC generally retained its
current market-based rate standards. The impact of this order and its effect on the generation
dominance proceeding cannot now be determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150;
Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding the proceeding initiated by the FERC in May&nbsp;2005 to
examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power,
Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of
which the Power Pool is operated, and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion
of Southern Power as a party to the IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the
FERC&#146;s standards of conduct applicable to utility companies that are transmission providers, and
(3)&nbsp;whether Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148;
rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just and reasonable.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On April&nbsp;19, 2007, the FERC approved, with certain modifications, the compliance filing
submitted by Southern Company on November&nbsp;6, 2006. The compliance plan largely involves
functional separation and information restrictions related to marketing activities conducted on
behalf of Southern Power. Implementation of the plan is not expected to have a material impact
on Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Retail Regulatory Matters</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#150;
Environmental Compliance Overview Plan&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on Mississippi
Power&#146;s annual environmental filing with the Mississippi PSC. In February&nbsp;2007, Mississippi Power
filed with the Mississippi PSC its annual ECO Plan evaluation for 2007. Mississippi Power
requested an average increase for retail customers of 86 cents per 1,000 KWH. This increase
represents approximately $7.5&nbsp;million in annual revenues for Mississippi Power. On April&nbsp;13, 2007,
the Mississippi PSC approved Mississippi Power&#146;s ECO Plan as filed. The new rates became effective
in May&nbsp;2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In April&nbsp;2007, the Mississippi PSC issued an order allowing Mississippi Power to defer
approximately $10.4&nbsp;million of certain reliability related maintenance costs beginning January&nbsp;1,
2007, and recover them over a four-year period beginning January&nbsp;1, 2008. These costs relate to
system upgrades and improvements that are now being made as a follow-up to the emergency repairs
that were made subsequent to Hurricane Katrina. As of September&nbsp;30, 2007, Mississippi Power had
incurred and deferred approximately $7.4&nbsp;million of such costs, of
which $1.4&nbsp;million is included in current assets as other regulatory assets and $6.0&nbsp;million is
included in long-term other regulatory assets on the Condensed Balance Sheets herein.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->108<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#150;
Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding storm restoration
costs in connection with Hurricane Katrina and a financing order issued by the Mississippi PSC that
authorized the issuance of $121.2&nbsp;million of storm restoration bonds under a state bond program.
The storm restoration bonds were issued by the Mississippi Development Bank on June&nbsp;1, 2007, on
behalf of the State of Mississippi. On June&nbsp;1, 2007, Mississippi Power received a grant payment of
$85.2&nbsp;million from the State of Mississippi representing recovery of $25.2&nbsp;million in retail storm
restoration costs incurred or to be incurred and $60.0&nbsp;million to increase Mississippi Power&#146;s
property damage reserve. On October&nbsp;9, 2007, Mississippi Power received an additional grant
payment of $17.6&nbsp;million for expenditures incurred to date for construction of a new storm
operations center. The funds received related to previously incurred storm restoration
expenditures have been accounted for as a government grant and have been recorded as a reduction to
the regulatory asset that was recorded as the storm restoration expenditures were incurred, in
accordance with FASB Statement No.&nbsp;71 (SFAS No.71), &#147;Accounting for the Effects of Certain Types of
Regulation.&#148; The funds received for storm restoration expenditures to be incurred were recorded as
a regulatory liability. Mississippi Power will receive further grant payments of up to $18.4
million as expenditures are incurred to construct a new storm operations center.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The funds received with respect to certain of the grants were funded through the Mississippi
Development Bank&#146;s issuance of tax-exempt bonds. Due to the tax-exempt status to the holders of
bonds for federal income tax purposes, the use of the proceeds is limited to expenditures that
qualify under the IRC. Prior to the receipt of the proceeds from the tax-exempt bonds in June and
October&nbsp;2007, management of Mississippi Power represented to the Mississippi Development Bank that
all expenditures to date qualify under the IRC. Should Mississippi Power use the proceeds for
non-qualifying expenditures, it could be required to return that portion of the proceeds received
from the tax-exempt bond issuance that was applied to non-qualifying expenditures. Management
expects that all future expenditures will also qualify and that no proceeds will be required to be
returned.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In order for the State of Mississippi to repay the bonds issued by the Mississippi Development
Bank, the State of Mississippi has established a system restoration charge that will be charged to
all retail electric utility customers within Mississippi Power&#146;s service area. This charge will be
collected by Mississippi Power through the retail customers&#146; monthly statement and remitted to the
State of Mississippi on a monthly basis. The system restoration charge is the property of the
State of Mississippi. Mississippi Power&#146;s only obligation is to collect and remit the proceeds of
the charge. Mississippi Power began collecting the system restoration charge on June&nbsp;20, 2007 and
remitted the first payment to the State of Mississippi on July&nbsp;17, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters &#150;
Performance Evaluation Plan&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements
of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#150; Performance Evaluation Plan&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for information regarding Mississippi Power&#146;s PEP. In September&nbsp;2007, the
Mississippi PSC staff and Mississippi Power entered into a stipulation that includes adjustments to
expenses which, if approved by the Mississippi PSC, would result in a one time credit to retail
customers of approximately $1.1&nbsp;million. In anticipation of that approval, Mississippi Power
recognized a regulatory liability and decreased retail revenues as of September&nbsp;30, 2007. The
final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters &#150;
System Restoration Rider&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#150; System Restoration Rider&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K for information regarding Mississippi Power&#146;s recovery of costs associated with property
damage. As of September&nbsp;30, 2007, Mississippi Power has estimated retail rate refunds or credits
of approximately $4.2
million related to SRR. Of this amount, $2.4&nbsp;million was recorded as a regulatory liability in the
fourth quarter 2006 and $1.8&nbsp;million was recorded as an increase in the regulatory liability in the
first nine months of 2007.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->109<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power is awaiting guidance from the Mississippi PSC regarding the disposition of these
items. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fuel Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power has an established fuel cost recovery factor that is approved by the Mississippi
PSC. Over the past several years, Mississippi Power experienced higher than expected fuel costs
for coal and gas, which led to an increase in the under recovered fuel costs. Mississippi Power is
required to file for an adjustment to the fuel cost recovery factor annually. The last such filing
was made in November&nbsp;2006 and the next filing will be in early November&nbsp;2007. The November&nbsp;2006
filing included projected costs for 2007 and previous years&#146; under recovered amounts. The
Mississippi PSC approved an increase in the fuel cost recovery factor effective January&nbsp;2007 in an
amount equal to 4.6% of total retail revenues. At September&nbsp;30, 2007, the under recovered balance
of fuel recorded in Mississippi Power&#146;s Condensed Balance Sheets herein was $45.9&nbsp;million compared
to $50.8&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2006. Mississippi Power&#146;s operating revenues are adjusted for
differences in actual recoverable fuel cost and amounts billed in accordance with the currently
approved cost recovery rate. Accordingly, changes to the billing factor will have no significant
effect on Mississippi Power&#146;s revenues or net income but will affect cash flow. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters &#150; Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; of
Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#150;</FONT> FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Other Matters&#148; of
Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information regarding the accounting treatment of
costs associated with Mississippi Power&#146;s generation resource planning, evaluation, and screening
activities. As of September&nbsp;30, 2007, Mississippi Power has incurred $7.3&nbsp;million in costs related
to these activities. Of this amount, $1.7&nbsp;million has been expensed in 2007 in other operations
and maintenance expenses. This represents the wholesale portion of such costs that would not
qualify as capital expenditures. The remaining balance of $5.6&nbsp;million is included in regulatory
assets on the Condensed Balance Sheets herein. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be
determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Mississippi Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive
governmental regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over
environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury,
common law nuisance, and citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as opacity and air
quality standards, has increased generally throughout the United States. In particular, personal
injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more
frequent. The ultimate outcome of such pending or potential litigation against Mississippi Power
cannot be predicted at this time; however, for current proceedings not specifically reported herein
or in Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K,
management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings
would have a material adverse effect on Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->110<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1
to the financial statements of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of
these policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s
results of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could
produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements.
See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete
discussion of Mississippi Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric
Utility Regulation, Contingent Obligations, Unbilled Revenues, and Plant Daniel Operating Lease.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Income Taxes</I>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On January&nbsp;1, 2007, Mississippi Power adopted FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 (FIN 48), &#147;Accounting for
Uncertainty in Income Taxes.&#148; FIN 48 requires companies to determine whether it is &#147;more likely
than not&#148; that a tax position will be sustained upon examination by the appropriate taxing
authorities before any part of the benefit can be recorded in the financial statements. It also
provides guidance on the recognition, measurement, and classification of income tax uncertainties,
along with any related interest and penalties. The provisions of FIN 48 were applied to all tax
positions beginning January&nbsp;1, 2007. The adoption of FIN 48 did not have a material impact on
Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fair Value Measurement</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;157 (SFAS No.&nbsp;157), &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; in September&nbsp;2006.
This standard provides guidance on how to measure fair value where it is permitted or required
under other accounting pronouncements. SFAS No.&nbsp;157 also requires additional disclosures about
fair value measurements.
Mississippi Power plans to adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;157 on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and is currently assessing the
impact of this standard.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fair Value Option</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In February&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;159 (SFAS No.&nbsp;159), &#147;Fair Value Option for
Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities &#151; Including an Amendment of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;115.&#148;
This standard permits an entity to choose to measure many financial instruments and certain other
items at fair value. Mississippi Power plans to adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;159 on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and is
currently assessing its impact to the extent the fair value option is elected.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s financial condition and liquidity position remained stable at September&nbsp;30,
2007. Net cash provided from operating activities totaled $147.4&nbsp;million for the first nine months
of 2007, compared to $103.1&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. The $44.3&nbsp;million
increase in cash provided from operating activities in the first nine months of 2007 is primarily
due to the receipt of grant proceeds of $74.3&nbsp;million, of
which $60&nbsp;million is being used to fund the property damage reserve and $14.3&nbsp;million is for
recovery of retail operations and maintenance storm restoration costs. Also contributing to the
increase were fuel and base rate
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->111<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">increases in effect in the first nine months of 2007 and cash outflows for restoration costs in the
first nine months of 2006 due to the impact of Hurricane Katrina. These sources of funds from
operating activities were offset by approximately $36&nbsp;million decrease in external insurance
proceeds received in 2007 as compared to 2006 related to Hurricane Katrina; approximately $23
million increase in the use of funds related to fossil fuel stock in 2007 compared to 2006,
primarily due to increases in both volume and price of fuel inventory; and approximately $92
million decrease in source of funds related to taxes in 2007 compared to 2006, primarily due to the
receipt of income tax refunds in 2006 related to Hurricane Katrina losses. Net cash used for
investing activities totaled $64&nbsp;million compared to $122.6&nbsp;million for the first nine months of
2006. This change of $58.6&nbsp;million is primarily due to the receipt of grant proceeds of $10.9
million related to retail capital storm restoration cost and cash outflows for restoration costs in
the first nine months of 2006 due to the impact of Hurricane Katrina. Net cash used for financing
activities totaled $78.4&nbsp;million for the first nine months of 2007, compared to net cash flow
provided from financing activities of $30.8&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. This
decrease of $109.2&nbsp;million is primarily due to the redemption of $36.1&nbsp;million of long-term debt
payable to an affiliate trust and the decrease in short-term borrowings.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Mississippi Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, lease
obligations, purchase commitments, preferred stock dividends, and trust funding requirements.
Approximately $1.1&nbsp;million will be required through September&nbsp;30, 2008 for redemptions and
maturities of long-term debt.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from
sources similar to those utilized in the past. Recently, Mississippi Power has primarily utilized
funds from operating cash flows, short-term debt, external security offerings, and equity
contributions from Southern Company. However, the amount, type, and timing of any future
financings, if needed, will depend upon, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and
other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150;
&#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s current liabilities frequently exceed current assets because of the continued
use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet scheduled maturities of long-term debt as well
as cash needs which can fluctuate significantly due to the seasonality of the business. To meet
short-term cash needs and contingencies, Mississippi Power had at September&nbsp;30, 2007, approximately
$9.2&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and $181&nbsp;million of unused committed credit arrangements
with banks. Of these unused facilities, $13.5&nbsp;million expire in 2007 and $167.5&nbsp;million expire in
2008. Approximately $39&nbsp;million of these credit arrangements contain provisions allowing two-year
term loans executable at expiration and $15&nbsp;million contain provisions allowing one-year term loans
executable at expiration. Mississippi Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed,
prior to expiration. See Note 6 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Bank
Credit Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. The credit
arrangements provide liquidity support to Mississippi Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable
rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper. Mississippi Power may also meet short-term cash
needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and
extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of Mississippi Power and other
Southern Company subsidiaries. At September&nbsp;30, 2007, Mississippi Power had $60.3&nbsp;million of
commercial paper outstanding. Management believes that the need for
working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial paper programs and lines of credit
without maintaining large cash balances.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->112<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Off-Balance Sheet
Financing Arrangements&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 7 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power under &#147;Operating Leases&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information related to
Mississippi Power&#146;s lease of a combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in
payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain
contracts that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit
rating change to below BBB- or Baa3. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales. At September&nbsp;30, 2007, the maximum potential collateral requirements were
$4.5&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power, along with all members of the Power Pool, is also party to certain agreements
that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating change to
below investment grade for Alabama Power and/or Georgia Power. These agreements are primarily for
natural gas and power price risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2007, Mississippi Power&#146;s
total exposure to these types of agreements was $26.7&nbsp;million.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2006 reporting period. In addition, Mississippi Power is
not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near
term.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Due to cost-based rate regulation, Mississippi Power has limited exposure to market volatility in
interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Mississippi Power enters into physical fixed-price
contracts for the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market.
Mississippi Power has also implemented retail fuel hedging programs at the instruction of the
Mississippi PSC and wholesale fuel hedging programs under agreements with wholesale customers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Unrealized gains and losses from mark-to-market adjustments on derivative contracts related to
Mississippi Power&#146;s fuel hedging programs are recorded as regulatory assets and liabilities.
Realized gains and losses from these programs are included in fuel expense and are recovered
through Mississippi Power&#146;s energy cost management clause. In addition, any unrealized gains and
losses on energy-related derivatives used to hedge anticipated purchases and sales are deferred in
other comprehensive income. Gains and losses on derivative contracts that are not designated as
hedges are recognized in the statements of income as incurred. These amounts were not material in
any period presented.
</DIV>

the financial statements as follows:

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Unrealized pre-tax gains (losses)&nbsp;recognized in income were not material for any period presented.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note
(F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power did not issue any long-term securities during the nine months ended September&nbsp;30,
2007. In April&nbsp;2007, Mississippi Power redeemed $36.1&nbsp;million of long-term debt payable to
affiliated trusts.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements, contractual
obligations, and storm restoration costs, Mississippi Power plans to continue, when economically
feasible, a program to retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost
capital if market conditions permit.
</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->114<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">THIRD QUARTER 2007 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2006<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2007 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2006

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power and its wholly-owned subsidiaries construct, acquire, own, and manage generation
assets and sell electricity at market-based prices in the southeastern wholesale market. Southern
Power continues to focus on executing its regional strategy in 2007 in the Southeast, one of the
fastest growing regions of the country, including potential acquisition and/or expansion
opportunities. Southern Power continues to face challenges at the federal regulatory level
relative to market power and affiliate transactions. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC
Matters&#148; herein for additional detail.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">To evaluate operating results and to ensure Southern Power&#146;s ability to meet its contractual
commitments to customers, Southern Power focuses on several key performance indicators. These
indicators consist of plant availability, peak season equivalent forced outage rate (EFOR), and net
income. Plant availability shows the percentage of time during the year that Southern Power&#146;s
generating units are available to be called upon to generate (the higher the better), whereas the
EFOR more narrowly defines the hours during peak demand times when Southern Power&#146;s generating
units are not available due to forced outages (the lower the better). For additional information
on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#150; &#147;Key Performance
Indicators&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Net Income</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s net income for the third quarter 2007 was $51.4&nbsp;million compared to $45.9&nbsp;million
for the corresponding period of 2006. For year-to-date 2007, earnings were $123.3&nbsp;million compared
to $97.6&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. These increases were primarily the result
of increased energy sales due to more favorable weather than the corresponding periods in 2006.
Also contributing to the increase in income were additional sales from the acquisition of Plant
Rowan in September&nbsp;2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Wholesale Revenues </I></B><B>&#150; </B><B><I>Affiliates and Wholesale Revenues </I></B><B>&#150; </B><B><I>Non-Affiliates</I></B>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Wholesale revenues for the third quarter 2007 were $345.3&nbsp;million compared to $267.9&nbsp;million for
the corresponding period of 2006. Wholesale revenues for year-to-date 2007 were $777.9&nbsp;million
compared to $599.7&nbsp;million for the corresponding period of 2006. Wholesale energy sales to
non-affiliates will vary depending on the energy demand of those customers and their generation
capacity, as well as the market cost of available energy compared to the cost of Southern Power.
Energy sales to affiliated companies within the Southern Company system will vary depending on
demand and the availability and cost of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->120<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">generating resources at each company. Sales to affiliate companies that are not covered by PPAs are
made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC. In the third quarter and year-to-date
2007, wholesale revenues to non-affiliates and affiliates increased when compared to the
corresponding periods in 2006. Wholesale revenues to non-affiliates increased $55.9&nbsp;million and
$120.4&nbsp;million during the respective periods, primarily due to short-term market energy sales and
sales from Plant Rowan. Wholesale revenues to affiliates increased $21.5&nbsp;million and $57.7&nbsp;million
during the respective periods, primarily due to increased demand under existing PPAs with
affiliates as a result of favorable weather within the Southern Company service territory as well
as higher fuel revenues due to an increase in natural gas prices in the third quarter and
year-to-date 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Power Sales Agreements&#148; of
Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Plant Acquisitions&#148; and
&#147;Power Sales Agreements&#148; herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Other revenues for the third quarter 2007 were $2.5&nbsp;million compared to $2.2&nbsp;million for the
corresponding period of 2006. Other revenues for year-to-date 2007 were $6.4&nbsp;million compared to
$3.8&nbsp;million for the corresponding period of 2006. These increases were primarily due to
transmission revenues related to a PPA which provides for recovery of substantially all direct
transmission costs. These transmission revenues do not have a significant impact on net income
since they are offset by associated expenses.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, total fuel and purchased power expenses were $186.3&nbsp;million compared to
$127.8&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. For year-to-date 2007, total fuel and
purchased power expenses were $362.8&nbsp;million compared to $254.7&nbsp;million for the same period in
2006. These increases were primarily due to increased generation and purchases in order to meet
the higher energy sales as well as higher fuel costs due to an increase in the average cost of
fuel.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, other operations and maintenance expenses were $32.1&nbsp;million compared to
$22.1&nbsp;million for the same period in 2006. This increase was primarily due to approximately $4.5
million of additional administrative and general expenses as a result of costs incurred to
implement the FERC compliance plan (see FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#151; Intercompany
Interchange Contract&#148; herein for additional information) and additional legal and staffing
expenses, $3.2&nbsp;million of increased other operations and maintenance expenses primarily related to
costs associated with Plant Rowan acquired in September&nbsp;2006, and $1.7&nbsp;million of increased
transmission expense partially related to a PPA which provides for recovery of substantially all
direct transmission costs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, other operations and maintenance expenses were $88.1&nbsp;million compared to
$67.8&nbsp;million for the same period in 2006. This increase was primarily due to approximately $6.7
million of additional administrative and general expenses as a result of costs incurred to
implement the FERC compliance plan and additional legal and staffing expenses, $6.4&nbsp;million of
increased other operations and maintenance expenses primarily related to Plants DeSoto and Rowan
acquired in June&nbsp;2006 and September&nbsp;2006, respectively, and $5.0&nbsp;million of increased transmission
expense partially related to a PPA which provides for recovery of substantially all direct
transmission costs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, depreciation and amortization was $18.4&nbsp;million compared to $16.9
million for the corresponding period in 2006. This increase was
primarily a result of additional depreciation related to Plant Rowan
acquired in September&nbsp;2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, depreciation and amortization was $55.1&nbsp;million compared to $47.5&nbsp;million
for the same period in 2006. This increase was primarily a result of additional depreciation related to Plants DeSoto and Rowan,
acquired in June&nbsp;2006 and September&nbsp;2006, respectively. These new plants contributed $7.1&nbsp;million
to the year-to-date increase. Higher depreciation rates also contributed approximately $0.8
million to the year-to-date increase due to the change in rates adopted in March&nbsp;2006. See Note 1
to the financial statements of Southern Power under &#147;Depreciation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Other Matters&#148; herein for additional
information regarding a new depreciation study currently underway.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, interest expense, net of amounts capitalized was $19.6&nbsp;million compared
$19.5&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. This increase was primarily due to interest on
the 30-year unsecured long-term senior notes issued in November&nbsp;2006 of $3.4&nbsp;million, offset by
increased capitalized interest of $1.7&nbsp;million on construction activities and a decrease in
interest on commercial paper of $1.6&nbsp;million due to lower borrowing levels.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, interest expense, net of amounts capitalized was $61.0&nbsp;million compared to
$60.5&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. This increase was primarily due to interest on
the 30-year unsecured long-term senior notes issued in November&nbsp;2006 of $10.0&nbsp;million, offset by
increased capitalized interest of $9.1&nbsp;million on construction activities and a decrease in
interest on commercial paper of $0.4&nbsp;million due to lower borrowing levels.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, other income (expense), net was $(2.0) million compared to $(2.2)
million for the corresponding period in 2006. This change was primarily due to lower unrealized
mark-to-market losses on derivative positions, partially offset by reduced interest income and
losses on asset retirements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2007, other income (expense), net was $(0.9) million compared to $1.1&nbsp;million for
the corresponding period in 2006. This change was primarily due to greater unrealized
mark-to-market losses on derivative positions in 2007 and losses on asset retirements.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the third quarter 2007, income taxes were $34.1&nbsp;million compared to $31.7&nbsp;million for the
corresponding period in 2006. For year-to-date 2007, income taxes were $81.4&nbsp;million compared to
$65.1&nbsp;million in the same period in 2006. These increases were primarily due to higher earnings
before taxes. Other factors include a higher state tax rate due to changes in state tax
apportionment rules and new activity in the state of North Carolina related to Plant Rowan acquired
in September&nbsp;2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Southern Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. Several factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Southern
Power&#146;s competitive wholesale energy business. These factors include the ability to achieve sales
growth while
containing costs. Another major factor is federal and state regulatory policy, which may impact
Southern Power&#146;s level of participation in the wholesale energy market. The level of future
earnings depends on
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->123<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">numerous factors, including regulatory matters, especially those related to affiliate contracts,
sales, creditworthiness of customers, total generating capacity available in the Southeast, and the
successful remarketing of capacity as current contracts expire. For additional information
relating to these issues, see RISK FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150;
Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements
of Southern Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K
for information regarding the proceedings initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess
Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory and in May&nbsp;2005 to
determine whether Southern Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based
rate analysis: transmission market power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal
dealing.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In late June and July&nbsp;2007, hearings were held in the December&nbsp;2004 proceeding and briefs to the
presiding ALJ were filed in August and September&nbsp;2007. Southern Power anticipates an initial
decision from the ALJ in November&nbsp;2007 on the issues that were set for hearing. The ultimate
outcome of this generation dominance proceeding cannot now be determined, but an adverse
decision by the FERC in a final order could result in refunds of approximately $0.7&nbsp;million,
plus interest.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On June&nbsp;21, 2007, the FERC issued an order terminating the May&nbsp;2005 proceeding pertaining to the
other three parts of the market-based rate analysis. In addition, on June&nbsp;21, 2007, the FERC
issued its final rule regarding market-based rate authority. The FERC generally retained its
current market-based rate standards. The impact of this order and its effect on the generation
dominance proceeding cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150;
Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Southern Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K for information regarding the proceeding initiated by the FERC in May&nbsp;2005 to
examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power,
Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of
which the Power Pool is operated, and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion
of Southern Power as a party to the IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the
FERC&#146;s standards of conduct applicable to utility companies that are transmission providers, and
(3)&nbsp;whether Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148;
rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just and reasonable.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On April&nbsp;19, 2007, the FERC approved, with certain modifications, the compliance filing
submitted by Southern Company on November&nbsp;6, 2006. The compliance plan largely involves
functional separation and information restrictions related to marketing activities conducted on
behalf of Southern Power.
Southern Power&#146;s cost of implementing the compliance plan, including the modifications, is
expected to average approximately $8&nbsp;million annually.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->124<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC)&nbsp;Project</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Construction Projects &#150;
Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC)&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
information regarding the development by Southern Power and the Orlando Utilities Commission (OUC)
of an IGCC project in Orlando, Florida at OUC&#146;s Stanton Energy site. Since the definitive
agreements relating to the development of the project were executed in December&nbsp;2005, the estimated
costs of the gasifier portion have increased due primarily to increases in commodity costs and
increased market demand for labor. Southern Power had the option under the original agreements to
end its participation in the gasifier portion of the project at the end of the project definition
phase, which has been completed. On March&nbsp;29, 2007, Southern Power&#146;s Board of Directors approved
the continuation and the completion of the design, engineering, and construction of the gasifier
portion of the project. Southern Power and OUC will share 65% and 35% of the estimated cost
increase, respectively, under the proposed amended agreements. In April&nbsp;2007, OUC approved its
portion of the cost increase, subject to the DOE&#146;s approval of the additional funding. On May&nbsp;8,
2007, SCS, as agent for Southern Power, and the DOE entered into an amendment to the February&nbsp;2006
cooperative agreement to increase the DOE&#146;s funding for the gasifier portion of the project by
$58.75&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern
Power is evaluating
the potential impacts of proposed federal and state
legislation and regulations on the gasifier portion of the IGCC project. Specifically, there is an
ongoing assessment of the State of Florida&#146;s governor&#146;s executive orders concerning future
emissions restrictions and the rules and regulations necessary for implementation of such orders.
For additional information on the governor&#146;s orders, see &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; Florida
Greenhouse Gas Executive Orders&#148; herein. As of October&nbsp;31, 2007, Southern Power&#146;s share of actual
and committed costs related to the gasifier portion of the IGCC project was approximately $45
million. These costs will increase as the project continues. The ultimate impact on Southern
Power&#146;s financial statements will be dependent on the evaluation and application of the State of
Florida&#146;s governor&#146;s executive orders and any other legislation or regulations, but could be
significant and possibly material. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Power Sales Agreements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Power Sales Agreements&#148; of
Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information on long-term PPAs. Southern
Power&#146;s PPAs with non-affiliated counterparties have provisions that require the posting of
collateral or an acceptable substitute guarantee in the event that the counterparty does not meet
certain rating or financial requirements. The PPAs are expected to provide Southern Power with a
stable source of revenue during their respective terms.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In October&nbsp;2006, Southern Power entered
into a PPA with Gulf Power for 292 MW annually from June
2009 through May&nbsp;2014 from Plant Dahlberg. The Florida PSC approved the agreement on March&nbsp;27,
2007. The FERC approved the agreement on July&nbsp;13, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In April&nbsp;2007, Southern Power
entered into two PPAs with Georgia Power. Under the first agreement,
Southern Power will provide Georgia Power with a total of 561 MW of capacity annually for the
period from June&nbsp;2010 through May&nbsp;2017 from Plant Wansley. Under the second agreement, Southern
Power will provide Georgia Power with a total of 292 MW of capacity annually for the period June
2010
through May&nbsp;2025 from Plant Dahlberg. The contracts provide for fixed capacity payments and
variable
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->125<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">energy payments based on actual energy delivered. These contracts were approved by the
Georgia PSC on October&nbsp;16, 2007 and are contingent upon approval from the FERC. The final outcome
of this matter cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of
Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information on the development by federal and state
environmental regulatory agencies of additional control strategies for emission of air pollution
from industrial sources, including electric generating facilities. Compliance with possible
additional federal or state legislation or regulations related to global climate change, air
quality, or other environmental and health concerns could also affect earnings. While Southern
Power&#146;s PPAs generally contain provisions that permit charging the counterparty with some of the
new costs incurred as a result of changes in environmental laws and regulations, the full impact of any such regulatory
or legislative changes cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Florida Greenhouse Gas Executive Orders</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of
Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information. On July&nbsp;13, 2007, the
Governor of the State of Florida signed three executive orders addressing reduction of greenhouse
gas emissions within the state, including statewide emission reduction targets beginning in 2017.
Included in the orders is a directive to the Secretary of Environmental Protection to develop rules
adopting maximum allowable emissions levels of greenhouse gases for electric utilities, consistent
with the statewide emission reduction targets, and a request to the Florida PSC to initiate
rulemaking requiring utilities to produce at least 20% of their electricity from renewable sources.
The impact of these orders on Southern Power will depend on the development, adoption, and
implementation of any rules governing greenhouse gas emissions, and the ultimate outcome cannot be
determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Southern Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive governmental
regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, common law nuisance, and
citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as opacity and air quality standards, has
increased generally throughout the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages
caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome
of such pending or potential litigation against Southern Power and its subsidiaries cannot be
predicted at this time; however, for current proceedings not specifically reported herein or in
Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K, management does
not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from any such proceedings would have a
material adverse effect on Southern Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power is currently conducting a depreciation study to update the composite lives for its
property, plant, and equipment. The impact of any possible depreciation rate changes cannot be
determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->126<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power prepares its consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described
in Note 1 to the financial statements of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the
application of these policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on
Southern Power&#146;s results of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and
measurements could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in the
financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150;
&#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form
10-K for a complete discussion of Southern Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates
related to Revenue Recognition, Asset Impairments, and Acquisition Accounting.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Income Taxes</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On January&nbsp;1, 2007, Southern Power adopted FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 (FIN 48), &#147;Accounting for
Uncertainty in Income Taxes.&#148; FIN 48 requires companies to determine whether it is &#147;more likely
than not&#148; that a tax position will be sustained upon examination by the appropriate taxing
authorities before any part of the benefit can be recorded in the financial statements. It also
provides guidance on the recognition, measurement, and classification of income tax uncertainties,
along with any related interest and penalties. The provisions of FIN 48 were applied to all tax
positions beginning January&nbsp;1, 2007. The adoption of FIN 48 did not have a material impact on
Southern Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fair Value Measurement</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;157 (SFAS No.&nbsp;157), &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; in September&nbsp;2006.
This standard provides guidance on how to measure fair value where it is permitted or required
under other accounting pronouncements. SFAS No.&nbsp;157 also requires additional disclosures about
fair value measurements. Southern Power plans to adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;157 on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and is
currently assessing the impact of this standard.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fair Value Option</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In February&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;159 (SFAS No.&nbsp;159), &#147;Fair Value Option for
Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities &#151; Including an Amendment of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;115.&#148;
This standard permits an entity to choose to measure many financial instruments and certain other
items at fair value. Southern Power plans to adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;159 on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and is currently
assessing its impact to the extent the fair value option is elected.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s financial condition and liquidity position remained stable at September&nbsp;30, 2007.
Net cash provided from operating activities totaled $255.3&nbsp;million for the first nine months of
2007, compared to $198.0&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2006. The $57.3&nbsp;million increase
in cash provided from operating activities in the first nine months of 2007 is primarily due to the
increase in net income, as
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->127<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">previously discussed, and cash received under billings for the
engineering, procurement, and construction services to build a combined cycle unit for OUC. Net
cash used for investing activities totaled $158.9&nbsp;million, compared to $451.2&nbsp;million for the
corresponding period in 2006. The $292.3&nbsp;million decrease is primarily due to the acquisition of
Plants DeSoto and Rowan in June&nbsp;2006 and September&nbsp;2006, respectively. Gross property additions to
utility plant of $149.6&nbsp;million in the first nine months of 2007 were primarily related to ongoing
construction activity at Plants Franklin and Oleander. Net cash used for financing activities
totaled $102.4&nbsp;million for the first nine months of 2007, compared to cash provided of $262.4
million for the corresponding period in 2006. This change was primarily due to higher short-term
borrowings and capital contributions in the first nine months of 2006 related to the acquisition of
Plants DeSoto and Rowan acquired in June&nbsp;2006 and September&nbsp;2006, respectively. Southern Power
paid dividends to Southern Company of $67.4&nbsp;million in the first nine months of 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Southern Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, maturing debt,
purchase commitments, and long-term service agreements. The total estimated cost of the gasifier
portion of the IGCC project for Southern Power has increased to $212&nbsp;million. As a result of the
increases in commodity costs and an increase in market demand for labor, the capital program of
Southern Power is projected to be $257.8&nbsp;million for 2007, $537.1&nbsp;million for 2008, and $865.0
million for 2009. These projections include Southern Power&#146;s share of the gasifier portion of the
IGCC project cost increase. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150;
&#147;Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC)&nbsp;Project&#148; herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In June, July, and August&nbsp;2007, Southern Power entered into agreements to purchase power in the
years 2007 to 2010. These purchase commitments will be $1.6&nbsp;million, $5.4&nbsp;million, $10.9&nbsp;million,
and $10.9&nbsp;million in the respective years.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those utilized in the past. Recently, Southern Power has primarily utilized funds from
operating cash flows, short-term debt, external security offerings and equity contributions from
Southern Company. However, the amount, type, and timing of any future financings, if needed, will
depend upon regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Southern
Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s current liabilities frequently exceed current assets because of the continued use
of short-term debt as a funding source as well as cash needs which can fluctuate significantly due
to the seasonality of the business. To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Southern
Power had at September&nbsp;30, 2007 approximately $24.0&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and a $400
million committed credit facility with a 2012 maturity. Borrowings of $60&nbsp;million under this
facility were
outstanding at September&nbsp;30, 2007. Subsequent to September&nbsp;30, 2007, Southern Power repaid the $60
million borrowing. Southern Power expects to renew its credit facility, as needed, prior to
expiration. See Note 6 to the financial statements of Southern Power under &#147;Bank Credit
Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. At September&nbsp;30, 2007,
Southern Power also had approximately $29.9&nbsp;million of commercial paper outstanding. Management
believes that the need for
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->128<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial paper
programs and lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit downgrade. There are certain contracts that could
require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change to BBB and
Baa2 or to BBB- or Baa3 or below. Generally, collateral may be provided with a Southern Company
guaranty, letter of credit, or cash. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales. At September&nbsp;30, 2007, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a BBB
and Baa2 rating were approximately $8.6&nbsp;million and at a BBB- or Baa3 rating were approximately
$267&nbsp;million. The maximum potential collateral requirements at a rating below BBB- or Baa3 were
approximately $454<BR>
million. In addition, through the acquisition of Plant Rowan, Southern Power assumed a PPA with
Duke Power Company LLC that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of
a downgrade to Southern Power&#146;s credit rating to below BBB- or Baa3. The amount of collateral
required would depend upon actual losses, if any, resulting from a credit downgrade, limited to
Southern Power&#146;s remaining obligations under the PPA. Generally, collateral may be provided by a
Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit, or cash.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power, along with the other members of the Power Pool, is also party to certain agreements
that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating change to
below investment grade for Alabama Power and/or Georgia Power. These agreements are primarily for
natural gas and power price risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2007, Southern Power&#146;s
total exposure to these types of agreements was $26.7&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power is exposed to market risks, including changes in interest rates, certain
energy-related commodity prices, and, occasionally, currency exchange rates. To manage the
volatility attributable to these exposures, Southern Power nets the exposures to take advantage of
natural offsets and enters into various derivative transactions for the remaining exposures
pursuant to Southern Power&#146;s policies in areas such as counterparty exposure and hedging practices.
Southern Power&#146;s policy is that derivatives are to be used primarily for hedging purposes.
Derivative positions are monitored using techniques that include market valuation and sensitivity
analysis.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2006 reporting period. In addition, Southern Power is
not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near
term.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Because energy from Southern Power&#146;s generating facilities is primarily sold under long-term PPAs
with tolling agreements and provisions shifting substantially all of the responsibility for fuel
cost to the counterparties, Southern Power&#146;s exposure to market volatility in commodity fuel prices
and prices of electricity is limited.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->129<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Unrealized pre-tax gains and losses on electric contracts used to hedge anticipated sales, and gas
contracts used to hedge anticipated purchases and sales, are deferred in other comprehensive
income. Gains and losses on derivative contracts that are not designated as hedges are recognized
in the statements of income as incurred.
</DIV>

<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES<BR>
ALABAMA POWER COMPANY<BR>
