<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS:</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(A)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>INTRODUCTION</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The condensed quarterly financial statements of the registrants included herein have been
prepared by each registrant, without audit, pursuant to the rules and regulations of the
SEC. The Condensed Balance Sheets as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 have been derived from the
audited financial statements of each registrant. In the opinion of each registrant&#146;s
management, the information regarding such registrant furnished herein reflects all
adjustments necessary to present fairly the results of operations for the periods ended
September&nbsp;30, 2007 and 2006. Certain information and footnote disclosures normally included
in annual financial statements prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States have been condensed or omitted pursuant to such rules and
regulations, although each registrant believes that the disclosures regarding such
registrant are adequate to make the information presented not misleading. Disclosure which
would substantially duplicate the disclosure in the latest Form 10-K and details which have
not changed significantly in amount or composition since the filing of the Form 10-K are
omitted from this Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q. Therefore, these Condensed Financial
Statements should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and the notes thereto
included in the Form 10-K. Certain prior period amounts have been reclassified to conform
to current period presentation. Due to seasonal variations in the demand for energy,
operating results for the periods presented do not necessarily indicate operating results
for the entire year.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(B)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>CONTINGENCIES AND REGULATORY MATTERS</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company, the traditional operating
companies, and Southern Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information relating to various
lawsuits and other contingencies.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><U>ENVIRONMENTAL MATTERS</U></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD><I>New Source Review Litigation</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company and Alabama Power under
&#147;Environmental Matters &#151; New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information regarding civil actions brought by the EPA alleging that Alabama
Power had violated the NSR provisions of the Clean Air Act and related state laws with
respect to certain of its coal-fired generating facilities. The plaintiffs&#146; appeal against
Alabama Power was stayed by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit pending the
U.S. Supreme Court&#146;s decision in a similar case against Duke Energy. On April&nbsp;2, 2007, the
U.S. Supreme Court issued an opinion in the Duke Energy case. The U.S. District Court for
the Northern District of Alabama has issued an order indicating a willingness to re-evaluate
its previous decision in light of the Supreme Court&#146;s Duke Energy opinion. The Eleventh
Circuit is now considering whether to proceed with the appeal or remand the case to the
District Court for further proceedings, and if so, whether to vacate the District Court&#146;s
original judgment in favor of Alabama Power. The final resolution of these claims cannot be
determined at this time.</TD>
</TR>


</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->132<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><I>Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company and Georgia Power under
&#147;Environmental Matters &#151; Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K
for additional information on litigation involving alleged violations of the Clean Air Act
at four of the units at Plant Wansley. On June&nbsp;18, 2007, the U.S. District Court for the
Northern District of Georgia approved a settlement between the parties resolving all
remaining issues and dismissed the case. There was no material impact on the financial
statements of Southern Company or Georgia Power.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><I>Environmental Remediation</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>During the second quarter 2007, Gulf Power increased its estimated liability for
environmental remediation projects by $12.8&nbsp;million as a result of changes in the cost
estimates to remediate substation sites. These projects have been approved by the Florida
PSC for recovery through the environmental cost recovery clause; therefore, there was no
impact on Gulf Power&#146;s net income as a result of these revised estimates. See Note 3 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Environmental Matters &#151; Environmental Remediation&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><U>MIRANT MATTERS</U></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Mirant was an energy company with businesses that included independent power projects and
energy trading and risk management companies in the U.S. and selected other countries. It
was a wholly-owned subsidiary of Southern Company until its initial public offering in
October&nbsp;2000. In April&nbsp;2001, Southern Company completed a spin-off to its shareholders of
its remaining ownership, and Mirant became an independent corporate entity. In July&nbsp;2003,
Mirant filed for voluntary reorganization under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. See
Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#151; Mirant
Bankruptcy&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding Southern Company&#146;s
contingent liabilities associated with Mirant, including guarantees of contractual
commitments, litigation, and joint and several liabilities in connection with the
consolidated federal income tax return<I>.</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><I>MC Asset Recovery Litigation</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#151; MC Asset
Recovery Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding a suit between MC
Asset Recovery, a special purpose subsidiary of the post-bankruptcy corporation that adopted
the name Mirant Corporation, and Southern Company. On March&nbsp;28, 2007, MC Asset Recovery
filed a Fourth Amended Complaint. Among other things, the Fourth Amended Complaint adds a
claim under the Federal Debt Collection Procedure Act (FDCPA)&nbsp;to avoid certain transfers
from Mirant to Southern Company and withdraws the breach of fiduciary duty claim the court
struck as a result of Southern Company&#146;s motion for summary judgment. MC Asset Recovery
claims to have standing to assert violations of the FDCPA and to recover property on behalf
of the Mirant debtors&#146; estates. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be determined at
this time.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><I>Mirant Securities Litigation</I></TD>

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#151; Mirant
Securities Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding a class action
lawsuit that several Mirant shareholders (plaintiffs)&nbsp;originally filed against Mirant and
certain Mirant officers in May&nbsp;2002. In November&nbsp;2002, Southern Company, certain former and
current senior officers of Southern Company, and 12 underwriters of Mirant&#146;s initial public
offering were added as defendants. On March&nbsp;24, 2006, the plaintiffs filed a motion for
reconsideration requesting that the court vacate that portion of its July&nbsp;14, 2003 order
dismissing the plaintiffs&#146; claims based upon Mirant&#146;s alleged improper energy trading and</TD>

2007, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia issued a final order and
judgment approving the December&nbsp;2006 settlement agreement. The deadline for appeal expired
with no appeal filed. There was no material impact on the financial statements of Southern
Company. This matter is now concluded.</TD>

</TR>

<TR>

    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company, the traditional operating
companies and Southern Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for information regarding the proceedings initiated by the FERC in December
2004 to assess Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory
and in May&nbsp;2005 to determine whether Southern Company satisfies the other three parts of the
FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission market power, barriers to entry, and
affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In late June and July&nbsp;2007, hearings were held in the December&nbsp;2004 proceeding and briefs to
the presiding ALJ were filed in August and September. Southern Company anticipates an
initial decision from the ALJ in November&nbsp;2007 on the issues that were set for hearing. The
ultimate outcome of this generation dominance proceeding cannot now be determined, but an
adverse decision by the FERC in a final order could result in total refunds of approximately
$19.7&nbsp;million, plus interest. The potential refunds include $3.9&nbsp;million for Alabama Power,
$5.8&nbsp;million for Georgia Power, $0.8&nbsp;million for Gulf Power, $8.4&nbsp;million for Mississippi
Power, and $0.7&nbsp;million for Southern Power, in each case plus interest.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On June&nbsp;21, 2007, the FERC issued an order terminating the May&nbsp;2005 proceeding pertaining to
the other three parts of the market-based rate analysis. In addition, on June&nbsp;21, 2007, the
FERC issued its final rule regarding market-based rate authority. The FERC generally
retained its current market-based rate standards. The impact of this order and its effect
on the generation dominance proceeding cannot now be determined.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

Savannah Electric, Southern Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the Power

submitted by Southern Company on November&nbsp;6, 2006. The compliance plan largely involves
functional separation and information restrictions related to marketing activities conducted
on behalf of Southern Power. Implementation of the plan is not expected to have a material

    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><U>INCOME TAX MATTERS</U></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><I>Leveraged Lease Transactions</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Income Tax Matters&#148; in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. The IRS challenged Southern Company&#146;s deductions related to three
international lease transactions (so-called SILO or sale-in-lease-out transactions), in
connection with its audits of Southern Company&#146;s 2000 through 2003 tax returns. In the
third quarter 2006, Southern Company paid the full amount of the disputed tax and the
applicable interest on the SILO issue for tax years 2000 &#151; 2001 and filed a claim for refund
which has now been denied by the IRS. The disputed tax amount is $79&nbsp;million and the related
interest is approximately $24&nbsp;million for these tax years. This payment, and the subsequent
IRS disallowance of the refund claim, closed the issue with the IRS and Southern Company has
initiated litigation in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia for a
complete refund of tax and interest paid for the 2000 and 2001 tax years. The estimated
amount of disputed tax and interest for tax years 2002 and 2003 is approximately $83&nbsp;million
and $15&nbsp;million, respectively. The tax and interest for these tax years was paid to the IRS
in the fourth quarter 2006. Southern Company has accounted for both payments in 2006 as
deposits. For tax years 2000 through 2006, Southern Company has claimed $284&nbsp;million in tax
benefits related to these SILO transactions challenged by the IRS. The ultimate impact on
Southern Company&#146;s net income will be dependent on the outcome of pending litigation, but
could be significant, and potentially material. Southern Company believes these
transactions are valid leases for U.S. tax purposes and the related deductions are
allowable. Southern Company is continuing to pursue resolution of these matters through
litigation; however, the ultimate outcome of these matters cannot now be determined.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Effective January&nbsp;1, 2007, Southern Company adopted both FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 (FIN
48), &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes&#148; and FASB Staff Position No.&nbsp;FAS 13-2 (FSP
13-2), &#147;Accounting for a Change or Projected Change in the Timing of Cash Flows Relating to
Income Taxes Generated by a Leveraged Lease Transaction.&#148; FIN 48 requires companies to
determine whether it is &#147;more likely than not&#148; that a tax position will be sustained upon
examination by the appropriate taxing authorities before any part of the benefit can be
recorded in the financial statements. It also provides guidance on the recognition,
measurement, and classification of income tax uncertainties, along with any related interest
and penalties. FSP 13-2 amends FASB Statement No.&nbsp;13, &#147;Accounting for Leases&#148; requiring
recalculation of the rate of return and the allocation of income whenever the projected
timing of the income tax cash flows generated by a leveraged lease is revised with
recognition of the resulting gain or loss in the year of the revision. FSP 13-2 also
requires that all recognized tax positions in a leveraged lease must be measured in
accordance with the criteria in FIN 48 and any changes resulting from FIN 48 must be
reflected as a change in an important lease assumption as of the date of adoption. In
adopting these standards, Southern Company concluded that a portion of the SILO tax benefits
were uncertain tax positions, as defined in FIN 48. Accordingly, Southern Company also
concluded that there
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->135<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>was a change in the timing of projected income tax cash flows and, as required by FSP 13-2,
recalculated the rate of return and allocation of income under the lease-in-lease-out (LILO)
and SILO transactions.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The cumulative effect of the initial adoption of FIN 48 and FSP 13-2 was recorded as an
adjustment to beginning retained earnings. For the LILO transaction settled with the IRS in
February&nbsp;2005, the cumulative effect of adopting FSP 13-2 was a $17&nbsp;million reduction in
beginning retained earnings. With respect to Southern Company&#146;s SILO transactions, the
adoption of FSP 13-2 reduced beginning retained earnings by $108&nbsp;million and the adoption of
FIN 48 reduced beginning retained earnings by an additional $15&nbsp;million. The adjustments to
retained earnings are non-cash charges and those related to
FSP 13-2 will be recognized as income over the remaining terms of the affected leases. Any
future changes in the projected or actual income tax cash flows will result in an additional
recalculation of the net investment in the leases and will be recorded currently in income.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><I>Synthetic Fuel Tax Credits</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Company has an investment in an entity that produces synthetic fuel and receives
tax credits under Section&nbsp;45K (formerly Section&nbsp;29) of the IRC. In accordance with Section
45K of the IRC, these tax credits are subject to limitation as the annual average price of
oil (as determined by the DOE) increases over a specified, inflation-adjusted dollar amount
published in the spring of the subsequent year. Southern Company, along with its partners
in this investment, has continued to monitor oil prices. Reserves against tax credits
earned in 2007 of $37.6&nbsp;million have been recorded in the first nine months of 2007 due to
projected phase-outs of the credits in 2007 as a result of current and projected future oil
prices. Additionally, the credits discussed above are not allowed under IRC Section&nbsp;45K for
any production after December&nbsp;31, 2007.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><I>Georgia State Income Tax Credits</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In September&nbsp;2007, 2006, and 2005, Georgia Power filed its 2006, 2005, and 2004 income tax
returns, respectively, which included state income tax credits for activity through Georgia
ports. Georgia Power has also filed additional similar claims for the years 2002 through 2004. The
Georgia Department of Revenue has not responded to these claims. On July&nbsp;24, 2007, Georgia
Power filed a complaint in the Superior Court of Fulton County to recover the credits
claimed for the years 2002 through 2004. If Georgia Power prevails, these claims could have
a significant, and possibly material, positive effect on Southern Company&#146;s and Georgia
Power&#146;s net income. If Georgia Power is not successful, payment of the related state tax
could have a significant, and possibly material, negative effect on Southern Company&#146;s and
Georgia Power&#146;s cash flow. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><U>INTEGRATED GASIFICATION COMBINED CYCLE (IGCC)&nbsp;PROJECT</U></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 4 to the financial statements of Southern Power under &#147;IGCC&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for additional information regarding the development by Southern Power and the Orlando
Utilities Commission (OUC)&nbsp;of an IGCC project in Orlando, Florida at OUC&#146;s Stanton Energy
site. On March&nbsp;29, 2007, Southern Power&#146;s Board of Directors approved the continuation and
the completion of the design, engineering, and construction of the gasifier portion of the
IGCC project. In April&nbsp;2007, OUC approved its portion of the cost increase, subject to the
DOE&#146;s approval of the additional funding. On May&nbsp;8, 2007, SCS, as agent for Southern Power,
and the DOE entered into an amendment to the February&nbsp;2006 cooperative agreement to increase
the DOE&#146;s funding for the gasifier portion of the IGCC project by $58.75&nbsp;million. Southern
Power is evaluating the potential impacts of proposed federal and state legislation
and regulations on the IGCC project. Specifically, there is an ongoing assessment of the
State of Florida&#146;s governor&#146;s executive orders concerning future emissions restrictions and
the rules and regulations necessary for implementation of such orders. As of October&nbsp;31,
2007, Southern Power&#146;s share of actual and committed costs related to the gasifier portion
of the IGCC project was approximately $45&nbsp;million. These costs will increase as the project
continues. The ultimate impact</TD>
</TR>

    <TD><U>PROPERTY TAX DISPUTE</U></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power and Gulf Power under &#147;Property Tax
Dispute&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on the property tax dispute with Monroe
County, Georgia. The administrative appeals and notices of arbitration have been expanded
to include tax year 2006. The appeals remain stayed pending the outcome of the related
litigation. On March&nbsp;30, 2007, the Georgia Court of Appeals reversed the trial court and
ruled that the Monroe County Board of Tax Assessors (Monroe Board) had exceeded its legal
authority and remanded the case for entry of an injunction prohibiting the Monroe Board from
collecting taxes based on its independent valuation of Plant Scherer. In April&nbsp;2007, the
Monroe Board filed a petition with the Georgia Supreme Court requesting review of the
decision of the Georgia Court of Appeals. On July&nbsp;16, 2007, the Georgia Supreme Court
agreed to hear the Monroe Board&#146;s requested review of this decision. The Georgia Supreme
Court heard oral arguments regarding the matter on October&nbsp;15, 2007. The suit could impact
all co-owners. Georgia Power and Gulf Power could be subject to total taxes through
September&nbsp;30, 2007 of up to $21.7&nbsp;million and $3.9&nbsp;million, respectively, plus penalties and
interest. In accordance with Gulf Power&#146;s unit power sales contract for Plant Scherer, such
property taxes would be recoverable from the customer. The ultimate outcome of this matter
cannot currently be determined.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><U>GULF POWER RIGHT OF WAY LITIGATION</U></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Right of Way Litigation&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K for information on the lawsuits related to the telecommunication use of
rights of way. In September&nbsp;2007, Gulf Power and its co-defendant in the Gadsden County
litigation reached a proposed settlement agreement with the plaintiffs that, if approved by
the trial court, will resolve all outstanding claims against Gulf Power in both the Gadsden
County litigation and the 2001 telecommunications company litigation. If so approved, the
settlement will have no material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements. Pending final
settlement approval, the ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(C)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>SEGMENT AND RELATED INFORMATION</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Company&#146;s reportable business segment is the sale of electricity in the Southeast
by the traditional operating companies and Southern Power. The &#147;All Other&#148; column includes
parent Southern Company, which does not allocate operating expenses to business segments.
Also, this category includes segments below the quantitative threshold for separate
disclosure. These segments include investments in synthetic fuels and leveraged lease
projects, telecommunications, and energy-related services. Southern Power&#146;s revenues from
sales to the traditional operating companies were $185&nbsp;million and $439&nbsp;million for the
three months and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2007, respectively, and $164&nbsp;million and
$381&nbsp;million for the three months and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2006, respectively.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->137<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(D)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>MISSISSIPPI POWER RETAIL REGULATORY MATTERS</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters
 &#151; Environmental Compliance Overview Plan&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on
Mississippi Power&#146;s annual environmental filing with the Mississippi PSC. In February&nbsp;2007,
Mississippi Power filed with the Mississippi PSC its annual ECO Plan evaluation for 2007.
Mississippi Power requested an average increase for retail customers of 86 cents per 1,000
KWH. This increase represents approximately $7.5&nbsp;million in annual revenues for Mississippi
Power. On April&nbsp;13, 2007, the Mississippi PSC approved Mississippi Power&#146;s ECO Plan as
filed. The new rates became effective in May&nbsp;2007.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In April&nbsp;2007, the Mississippi PSC issued an order allowing Mississippi Power to defer
approximately $10.4&nbsp;million of certain reliability related maintenance costs beginning
January&nbsp;1, 2007, and recover them over a four-year period beginning January&nbsp;1, 2008. These
costs relate to system upgrades and improvements that are now being made as a follow-up to
the emergency repairs that were made subsequent to Hurricane Katrina. As of September&nbsp;30,
2007, Mississippi Power had incurred and deferred approximately $7.4&nbsp;million of such costs,
of which $1.4&nbsp;million is included in current assets as other
regulatory assets and $6.0&nbsp;million is included in long-term
other regulatory assets on the Condensed Balance Sheets herein.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters
 &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding storm
restoration costs in</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt"><TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">


</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>connection with Hurricane Katrina and a financing order issued by the Mississippi PSC that
authorized the issuance of $121.2&nbsp;million of storm restoration bonds under a state bond
program. The storm restoration bonds were issued by the Mississippi Development Bank on
June&nbsp;1, 2007, on behalf of the State of Mississippi. On June&nbsp;1, 2007, Mississippi Power
received a grant payment of $85.2&nbsp;million from the State of Mississippi representing
recovery of $25.2&nbsp;million in retail storm restoration costs incurred or to be incurred and
$60.0&nbsp;million to increase Mississippi Power&#146;s property damage reserve. On October&nbsp;9, 2007,
Mississippi Power received an additional grant payment of $17.6&nbsp;million for expenditures
incurred to date for construction of a new storm operations center. The funds received
related to previously incurred storm restoration expenditures have been accounted for as a
government grant and have been recorded as a reduction to the regulatory asset that was
recorded as the storm restoration expenditures were incurred, in accordance with FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;71, &#147;Accounting for the Effects of Certain Types of Regulation.&#148; The funds
received for storm restoration expenditures to be incurred were recorded as a regulatory
liability. Mississippi Power will receive further grant payments of up to $18.4&nbsp;million as
expenditures are incurred to construct a new storm operations center.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The funds received with respect to certain of the grants were funded through the Mississippi
Development Bank&#146;s issuance of tax-exempt bonds. Due to the tax-exempt status to the
holders of bonds for federal income tax purposes, the use of the proceeds is limited to
expenditures that qualify under the IRC. Prior to the receipt of the proceeds from the
tax-exempt bonds in June and October&nbsp;2007, management of Mississippi Power represented to
the Mississippi Development Bank that all expenditures to date qualify under the IRC.
Should Mississippi Power use the proceeds for non-qualifying expenditures, it could be
required to return that portion of the proceeds received from the tax-exempt bond issuance
that was applied to non-qualifying expenditures. Management expects that all future
expenditures will also qualify and that no proceeds will be required to be returned.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In order for the State of Mississippi to repay the bonds issued by the Mississippi
Development Bank, the State of Mississippi has established a system restoration charge that
will be charged to all retail electric utility customers within Mississippi Power&#146;s service
area. This charge will be collected by Mississippi Power through the retail customers&#146;
monthly statement and remitted to the State of Mississippi on a monthly basis. The system
restoration charge is the property of the State of Mississippi. Mississippi Power&#146;s only
obligation is to collect and remit the proceeds of the charge. Mississippi Power began
collecting the system restoration charge on June&nbsp;20, 2007 and remitted the first payment to
the State of Mississippi on July&nbsp;17, 2007.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters
 &#151; Performance Evaluation Plan&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding
Mississippi Power&#146;s PEP. In September&nbsp;2007, the Mississippi PSC staff and Mississippi Power
entered into a stipulation that includes adjustments to expenses which, if approved by the
Mississippi PSC, would result in a one time credit to retail customers of approximately $1.1
million. In anticipation of that approval, Mississippi Power recognized a regulatory
liability and decreased retail revenues as of September&nbsp;30, 2007. The final outcome of this
matter cannot now be determined.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters
 &#151; System Restoration Rider&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding Mississippi
Power&#146;s recovery of costs associated with property damage. As of September&nbsp;30, 2007,
Mississippi Power has estimated retail rate refunds or credits of approximately $4.2&nbsp;million
related to the System Restoration Rider (SRR). Of this amount, $2.4&nbsp;million was recorded as
a regulatory liability in the fourth quarter 2006 and $1.8&nbsp;million was recorded as an
increase in the regulatory liability in the first nine months of 2007. Mississippi Power is
awaiting guidance from the Mississippi PSC regarding the disposition of these items. The
final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Mississippi Power is undergoing a feasibility assessment of a proposed IGCC project in
Kemper County, Mississippi. In December&nbsp;2006, the Mississippi PSC approved Mississippi
Power&#146;s request for
</TD>
</TR>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>accounting treatment of the costs associated with Mississippi Power&#146;s generation resource
planning, evaluation, and screening activities. The Mississippi PSC gave Mississippi Power
the authority to create and recognize a regulatory asset for such costs. As of September
30, 2007, Mississippi Power has incurred $7.3&nbsp;million in costs related to these activities.
Of this amount, $1.7&nbsp;million has been expensed in 2007 in other operations and maintenance
expenses. This represents the wholesale portion of such costs that would not qualify as
capital expenditures. The remaining balance of $5.6&nbsp;million is included in regulatory
assets on the Condensed Balance Sheets herein. The final outcome of this matter cannot now
be determined.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>gain of $0.1&nbsp;million, respectively, for Southern Power, and was immaterial for the
traditional operating companies.</TD>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The amounts reclassified from other comprehensive income to fuel expense and revenues for
the three- and nine-month periods ending September&nbsp;30, 2007 and 2006 were immaterial for
each registrant. Additionally, no material ineffectiveness has been recorded in net income
for the three and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2007 and 2006. The amounts expected to be
reclassified from other comprehensive income to fuel expense and revenue for the next
twelve-month period ending September&nbsp;30, 2008 is also immaterial for each registrant.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>During 2006 and 2007, Southern Company entered into derivative transactions to reduce its
exposure to a potential phase-out of certain income tax credits related to synthetic fuel
production in 2007. In accordance with Section&nbsp;45K of the IRC, these tax credits are
subject to limitation as the annual average price of oil increases. At September&nbsp;30, 2007,
the fair value of all derivative transactions related to synthetic fuel production was a
$39.3&nbsp;million net asset. For the three and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2007, the fair
value gain recognized in income to mark the transactions to market was $23.6&nbsp;million and
$23.4&nbsp;million, respectively. For the three and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2006, the
fair value loss recognized in income for similar derivative transactions was $23.3&nbsp;million
and $19.4&nbsp;million, respectively.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The amount reclassified from other comprehensive income to interest expense for the three
and nine-month periods ending September&nbsp;30, 2007 was a loss of $3.9&nbsp;million and $11.2
million, respectively, for Southern Company, was a loss of $3.4&nbsp;million and $9.9&nbsp;million,
respectively, for Southern Power, and was immaterial for the traditional operating
companies. For the comparative three and nine-month periods in 2006, the amount was a gain
of $2.3&nbsp;million and $7.6&nbsp;million, respectively, for Alabama Power, was a loss of $3.0&nbsp;million
and $8.9&nbsp;million, respectively, for Southern Power, and was immaterial for all other
registrants. No material ineffectiveness has been recorded in net income for any of the
periods reported.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->141<!-- /Folio -->

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">(H)</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>EFFECTIVE TAX RATES</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Company&#146;s effective tax rate was 34.1% for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30,
2007, as compared to 34.2% for the same period in 2006. The effective tax rate decreased
due to additional AFUDC equity recorded by Georgia Power and Gulf Power and by the increase
in the IRC Section&nbsp;199 domestic production deduction. These decreases were offset by a
reduction in synthetic fuel tax credits net of reserves. See Note 5 to the financial
statements of Southern Company, Georgia Power, and Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information
on each company&#146;s effective income tax rate.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In connection with its construction program, Georgia Power recorded an increase of
approximately $25.4&nbsp;million in AFUDC equity, which is not taxable, during the nine months
ended September&nbsp;30, 2007, as compared to the prior year. Georgia Power also recorded
certain federal deductions and state income tax credits, which together with the increased
AFUDC equity, resulted in a lower effective income tax rate of 35.7% for the nine months
ended September&nbsp;30, 2007 when compared to 36.6% in the same period in 2006. See Note (B)
herein for additional information regarding the pending litigation associated with the state
tax credits.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In connection with its construction program, Gulf Power recorded an increase of
approximately $1.3&nbsp;million in AFUDC equity, which is not taxable, during the nine months
ended September&nbsp;30, 2007, as compared to the prior year. Gulf Power also had an increase in
the deduction created by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 as discussed below, which
together with the increased AFUDC equity,</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->143<!-- /Folio -->

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt"><TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">



</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>resulted in a lower effective income tax rate of 36.6% for the nine months ended September
30, 2007 when compared to 37.5% in the same period in 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 created a tax deduction for the portion of income
attributable to United States production activities as defined in IRC Section&nbsp;199. The
deduction is equal to a stated percentage of the taxpayer&#146;s qualified production activities.
The percentage is phased in over the years 2005 through 2010 with a 3% rate applicable to
the years 2005 and 2006, a 6% rate applicable for years 2007 through 2009, and a 9% rate
applicable for all years after 2009. This increase from 3% in 2006 to 6% in 2007 resulted
in an additional $13&nbsp;million in tax deductions in 2007 compared to 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Company recorded net synthetic fuel tax credits as of the nine months ended
September&nbsp;30, 2007 that are $16.2&nbsp;million less than the net synthetic fuel tax credits
recorded for the same period in 2006. See Note (B)&nbsp;herein for additional information
regarding the production of synthetic fuel tax credits in 2007. The impact of the reduction
in net synthetic fuel tax credits is an increase in Southern Company&#146;s effective tax rate
for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2007 as compared to the same period in 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(I)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>ADOPTION OF FIN 48</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On January&nbsp;1, 2007, Southern Company, the traditional operating companies, and Southern
Power adopted FIN 48, which requires companies to determine whether it is &#147;more likely than
not&#148; that a tax position will be sustained upon examination by the appropriate taxing
authorities before any part of the benefit can be recorded in the financial statements. It
also provides guidance on the recognition, measurement, and classification of income tax
uncertainties, along with any related interest and penalties. Prior to adoption of FIN 48,
Southern Company had unrecognized tax benefits of approximately $65&nbsp;million, which included
approximately $62&nbsp;million for Georgia Power. As of adoption, an additional $146&nbsp;million of
unrecognized tax benefits were recorded, which resulted in a total balance of $211&nbsp;million.
The $146&nbsp;million is associated with a tax timing difference which was recorded by
reclassifying a deferred tax liability to an unrecognized tax benefit. Of the total $211
million unrecognized tax benefits, $65&nbsp;million would impact Southern Company&#146;s effective tax
rate if recognized, which includes $62&nbsp;million for Georgia Power. For the first nine months
of 2007, the total amount of unrecognized tax benefits increased by $39.7&nbsp;million, resulting
in a balance of $250.7&nbsp;million as of September&nbsp;30, 2007. Of the $39.7&nbsp;million increase in
unrecognized tax benefits, $23.1&nbsp;million would impact Southern Company&#146;s effective tax rate
if recognized.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Company classifies interest on tax uncertainties as interest expense. The net
amount of interest accrued as of adoption was $24&nbsp;million, which resulted in a reduction to
beginning 2007 retained earnings of approximately $15&nbsp;million, net of tax. The other
registrants&#146; retained earnings balances were not impacted by the adoption of FIN 48. Net
interest accrued for the FIN 48 liability as of September&nbsp;30, 2007 was $30.3&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Company files a consolidated federal income tax return. The IRS has audited and
closed all tax returns prior to 2004. Southern Company also files income tax returns in
various states. The audits for these returns have either been concluded, or the statute of
limitations has expired, for years prior to 2002.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>It is reasonably possible that the amount of the unrecognized benefit with respect to
certain of Southern Company&#146;s unrecognized tax positions will significantly increase or
decrease within the next twelve months. The possible settlement of the SILO litigation
or the Georgia state tax credits litigation or the conclusion or settlement of federal or
state audits could impact the balances significantly. At this time, an estimate of the
range of reasonably possible outcomes cannot be determined. See Note (B)&nbsp;herein for
additional information regarding the implementation of FIN 48 and current litigation
concerning deductions related to the SILO transactions and the Georgia state tax credits.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->144<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt"><TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">



</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(J)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>ALABAMA POWER RETAIL REGULATORY MATTERS</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Alabama Power has established fuel cost recovery rates approved by the Alabama PSC. Alabama
Power&#146;s under recovered fuel costs as of September&nbsp;30, 2007 totaled $307&nbsp;million as compared
to $301&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2006. As a result of the increasing level of under
recovered fuel costs, on June&nbsp;18, 2007, the Alabama PSC ordered Alabama Power to increase
its Rate ECR factor to 3.1 cents per KWH from 2.4 cents per KWH, effective with billings
beginning July&nbsp;2007 for the 30-month period ending December&nbsp;2009. This change represents on
average an increase of approximately $7.37 per month for a customer billing of 1,000 KWH.
This increase is intended to permit the recovery of energy costs based on an estimate of
future energy costs, as well as the collection of the existing under recovered energy costs
by the end of 2009. During the 30-month period, Alabama Power will be allowed to include a
carrying charge associated with the under recovered fuel costs in the fuel expense
calculation. In the event the application of this increased Rate ECR factor results in an
over recovered position during this period, Alabama Power will pay interest on any such over
recovered balance at the same rate used to derive the carrying costs. As a result of the
order, Alabama Power classified $69&nbsp;million of the under recovered regulatory clause
receivable as deferred charges and other assets in the Condensed Balance Sheet as of
September&nbsp;30, 2007 herein.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, Alabama Power had a deficit balance in the deferred natural
disaster reserve account of approximately $16.8&nbsp;million. In June&nbsp;2007, Alabama Power fully
recovered its prior storm costs related to Hurricanes Dennis and Katrina. As a result
customer rates decreased by $1.73 per month per residential customer account and $4.29 per
month per non-residential customer account beginning with July&nbsp;2007 billings. Alabama Power
continues to collect a monthly Rate NDR charge to establish and maintain a target reserve
balance of $75&nbsp;million for future storms. At September&nbsp;30, 2007, Alabama Power had
accumulated a balance of $23.1&nbsp;million in the target reserve for future storms, which is
included in the balance sheets under &#147;Other Regulatory Liabilities.&#148; See Note 3 to the
financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#151; Natural Disaster
Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(K)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>GEORGIA POWER RETAIL REGULATORY MATTERS</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Georgia Power is currently operating under a three-year retail rate order that expires
December&nbsp;31, 2007. Under the terms of the existing order, earnings are evaluated annually
against a retail return on common equity range of 10.25% to 12.25%. Two-thirds of any
earnings above the 12.25% return are applied to rate refunds, with the remaining one-third
retained by Georgia Power. The order required Georgia Power to file a general rate case by
July&nbsp;1, 2007.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On June&nbsp;29, 2007, Georgia Power filed a request to increase retail base rates with the
Georgia PSC. The request includes an increase effective January&nbsp;1, 2008 of approximately
$406&nbsp;million, or 5.98%, in retail revenues, based on a future test year ending July&nbsp;31, 2008
and a proposed retail return on common equity of 12.5%. The majority of the increase in
retail revenues is being requested to cover the costs of environmental compliance and
continued investment in new generation, transmission, and distribution facilities to support
growth and ensure reliability. The remainder of the increase would include recovery of
higher operations, maintenance, and other investment costs to meet the rising demand for
electricity. Hearings on Georgia Power&#146;s direct testimony were held in early October. In
direct testimony filed on October&nbsp;22, 2007, the Georgia PSC staff proposed certain
adjustments to Georgia Power&#146;s general rate case that indicates a $21&nbsp;million revenue
surplus. Georgia Power disagrees with the majority of the staff&#146;s proposed adjustments.
Hearings on Georgia PSC staff&#146;s and intervenors&#146; direct testimony will be held in early
November. Georgia Power&#146;s rebuttal hearings will occur later the same month. Georgia Power
expects the Georgia PSC to issue a final order in this matter on December&nbsp;20, 2007. In
addition to the traditional test period request, Georgia Power filed information for a
three-year rate plan option that includes additional increases of approximately $189
million, or 2.62%, and $41&nbsp;million, or 0.56%, in retail revenues effective January&nbsp;1, 2009
and 2010, respectively, to cover the costs of additional
environmental controls and certified PPAs. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be
determined. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company and Georgia Power
under &#147;Georgia Power</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->145<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; and &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#151; Rate Plans,&#148; respectively, in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(L)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>NUCLEAR FUEL DISPOSAL COST LITIGATION</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 1 to the financial statements of Southern Company, Alabama Power, and Georgia
Power under &#147;Nuclear Fuel Disposal Costs&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information
regarding the litigation brought by Alabama Power and Georgia Power against the government for
breach of contracts related to the disposal of spent nuclear fuel. On July&nbsp;9, 2007, the
U.S. Court of Federal Claims awarded Georgia Power a total of $30&nbsp;million, based on its
ownership interests, and awarded Alabama Power $17.3&nbsp;million, representing all of the
direct costs of the expansion of spent nuclear fuel storage facilities from 1998 through
2004. In August&nbsp;2007, the government filed a motion for reconsideration, which was denied on November&nbsp;1, 2007.
The government has 60 days in which to file an appeal. The final outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this time, but no
material impact on net income is expected. No amounts have been recognized in the
financial statements as of September&nbsp;30, 2007.</TD>
</TR>


</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->146<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

incorporated herein by reference.)</TD>

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-10.A.1
<SEQUENCE>2
<FILENAME>x10a1.htm
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE> </TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY bgcolor="#ffffff">




<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt;text-align:right;'><b><font size=2>Exhibit 10(a)1</font></b></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt;text-align:center;'><b><font SIZE=2>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY</font></b></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt;text-align:center;'><b><font SIZE=2>OMNIBUS INCENTIVE COMPENSATION PLAN</font></b></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt;text-align:center;'><b><font SIZE=2>FORM OF RESTRICTED STOCK AWARD AGREEMENT</font></b></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:5pt; margin-top:5pt;text-align:left;'><font size=2>Your Restricted Stock Grant is subject to the following terms and conditions:</font></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-left:1in; text-indent:-0.5in;text-align:left;'><font size=2>&nbsp;</font></p>

<table  border="0" cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style='margin-left:.5in;border-collapse:collapse; '>
    <tr >
        <td width="48" valign=top >
            <p style='margin-left:0pt;text-indent:0pt;text-align:left;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt'><font size=2>1.</font></p> </td>
        <td  valign=top >
            <p style='margin-left:0pt;text-indent:0pt;text-align:left;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt'><u><font size=2>Grant.</font></u><font size=2>  The Compensation and Management Succession Committee (the &#147;Committee&#148;)  has granted to you (the &#147;Participant&#148;) a Restricted Stock Award of </font><b><font size=2>_________</font></b><font size=2> shares (the &#147;Restricted Stock&#148;) of common stock of the Southern Company (the &#147;Company&#148;), par value $5 per share (the &#147;Common Stock&#148;), which shares shall be subject to the restrictions herein.  The Restricted Stock Award was granted on __________.  This award is governed by the Southern Company Omnibus Incentive Compensation Plan, as amended from time to time (the &#147;Plan&#148;).</font></p> </td> </tr></table>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-left:0.5in;text-align:left;'><font size=2>&nbsp;</font></p>


<table  border="0" cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style='margin-left:.5in;border-collapse:collapse; '>
    <tr >
        <td width="48" valign=top >
            <p style='margin-left:0pt;text-indent:0pt;text-align:left;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt'><font size=2>2.</font></p> </td>
        <td  valign=top >
            <p style='margin-left:0pt;text-indent:0pt;text-align:left;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt'><u><font size=2>Terms.</font></u><font size=2>  Terms in this Award Agreement that are defined in the Plan will have the meanings ascribed to them in the Plan.  If there is any inconsistency between the terms of this Award Agreement and the terms of the Plan, the Plan&#146;s terms will supersede and replace the conflicting terms of this Award Agreement.</font></p> </td> </tr></table>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt;text-align:left;'><font size=2>&nbsp;</font></p>


<table  border="0" cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style='margin-left:.5in;border-collapse:collapse; '>
    <tr >
        <td width="48" valign=top >
            <p style='margin-left:0pt;text-indent:0pt;text-align:left;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt'><font size=2>3.</font></p> </td>
        <td  valign=top >
            <p style='margin-left:0pt;text-indent:0pt;text-align:left;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt'><u><font size=2>Vesting and Period of Restriction.</font></u><font size=2>  The Restricted Stock shall vest on the ________ anniversary of this grant (_______ __, 20__) (the &#147;Vesting Date&#148;).  With respect to any share of Restricted Stock, the period between the date of grant and the corresponding date of delivery of such share in accordance herewith shall be referred to as the &#147;Period of Restriction.&#148;</font></p> </td> </tr></table>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt;text-align:left;'><font size=2>&nbsp;</font></p>


<table  border="0" cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style='margin-left:.5in;border-collapse:collapse; '>
    <tr >
        <td width="48" valign=top >
            <p style='margin-left:0pt;text-indent:0pt;text-align:left;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt'><font size=2>4.</font></p> </td>
        <td  valign=top >
            <p style='margin-left:0pt;text-indent:0pt;text-align:left;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt'><u><font size=2>Custody of Shares</font></u><font size=2>. The Company shall retain custody of shares of the Restricted Stock for the duration of the Period of Restriction.</font></p> </td> </tr></table>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt;text-align:left;'><font size=2>&nbsp;</font></p>


<table  border="0" cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style='margin-left:.5in;border-collapse:collapse; '>
    <tr >
        <td width="48" valign=top >
            <p style='margin-left:0pt;text-indent:0pt;text-align:left;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt'><font size=2>5.</font></p> </td>
        <td  valign=top >
            <p style='margin-left:0pt;text-indent:0pt;text-align:left;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt'><u><font size=2>Impact of Termination of Employment.</font></u><font size=2>  The rights of the Participant to the Restricted Stock in the event of a termination of employment in the Period of Restriction are determined according to the following table: </font></p> </td> </tr></table>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-left:1in; text-indent:-0.5in;text-align:left;'><font size=2>&nbsp;</font></p>


<table  border="0" cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style='margin-left:1in;border-collapse:collapse; '>
    <tr style='page-break-inside:avoid'>
        <td width="281" valign=bottom style='border-bottom: solid black 1.0pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;margin-left: 0in'><b><font size=2>Termination of Employment Event</font></b></p> </td>
        <td width="116" valign=bottom style='border-bottom: solid black 1.0pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;margin-left: 0in'><b><font size=2>Impact </font></b><br> <b><font size=2>on Restricted Stock</font></b></p> </td> </tr>
    <tr style='page-break-inside:avoid'>
        <td width="281" valign=top style='padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
        <td width="116" valign=top style='padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td> </tr>
    <tr style='page-break-inside:avoid'>
        <td width="281" style='padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><font size=2>Disability</font><sup><font size=2>1</font></sup></p> </td>
        <td width="116" style='padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><font size=2>Vest fully</font></p> </td> </tr>
    <tr style='page-break-inside:avoid'>
        <td width="281" style='padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><font size=2>Death</font></p> </td>
        <td width="116" style='padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><font size=2>Vest fully</font></p> </td> </tr>
    <tr style='page-break-inside:avoid'>
        <td width="281" style='padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><font size=2>Any other type of termination not for cause</font><sup><font size=2>2</font></sup></p> </td>
        <td width="116" style='padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><font size=2>Forfeited</font></p> </td> </tr>
    <tr style='page-break-inside:avoid'>
        <td width="281" style='padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><font size=2>Any termination for cause</font><sup><font size=2>2/3</font></sup></p> </td>
        <td width="116" style='padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
            <p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><font size=2>Forfeited</font></p> </td> </tr></table>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:5pt; margin-left:0.5in;text-align:left;'><font size=2>&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-left:1in;text-align:left;'><sup><font size=2>1</font></sup><font size=2>Disability means any physical or mental condition which would qualify you for a disability benefit under the long-term disability plan maintained by the Company and applicable to you, or if no such disability plan exists, as determined by the Committee. </font></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-left:0.5in; text-indent:0.5in;text-align:left;'><sup><font size=2>2</font></sup><font size=2>Cause is determined by the Committee.</font></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-left:1in;text-align:left;'><sup><font size=2>3</font></sup><font size=2>Any termination for cause includes any type of termination (including, but not limited to, a voluntary or involuntary resignation by you, a voluntary or involuntary termination by the Company, your termination with severance, your retirement, or your termination because of a disability) if such termination is related to cause.</font></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-left:0.5in; text-indent:-0.06in;text-align:left;'><font size=2>&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-left:1in;text-align:left;'><font size=2>Restricted Stock that is not vested at the time of your termination of employment will, coincident therewith, terminate and be of no force or effect.</font></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-left:1.04in; text-indent:-0.52in;text-align:left;'><font size=2>&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt;text-align:left;'><font size=2>&nbsp;</font></p>
